p.seg: The two royal Wives of You Yu
were the daughters of Lord Yao;
The elder was E Huang
and the second was Nyu Ying.
Shun's father was perverse, and his mother stupid;
his father was called Gu Sou or the Blind Old Man
and yis younger brother was designated Xiang.
He, [Gu Sou] strutted about in a sumptuous manner
but Shun was agreeable and accommodating to him,
and served him with filial devotion.
Though the mother hated Shun and loved Xiang,
he [Shun] controlled himself internally
and manifested no ill will toward her.
When Si Yue (President of the Princes) made him known to Yao
to look after his home. [observe him within the family CH]
The two daughters took up the service of Shun amid his furrowed fields
and did not, because they were daughters of the Son of Heaven, act proudly or disparagingly,
but were unassuming, respectful, and frugal,
taking thought of how to fulfill the role of wife.
[Once] Gu Sou plotted with Xiang to kill Shun
by giving him an order to plaster the granary.
Shun returned home and told the two daughters saying:
"My father and mother have ordered je to plaster the granary
and I shall go."
The two daughters said:
"Go, to be sure!"
While Shun was attending to the granary,
Gu Sou set fire to it
after the ladder had been removed.
But Shun hastily made his escape.
Xiang returned to plot again with his father and mother
by ordering Shun to deepen a well.
When Shun informed the two daughters,
they said:
"You had better go"
Shun went down to deepen the well
and planned his going in and coming out,
but they [not knowing that] proceeded to cover it up.
Shun came out secretly
and they could not kill him that time. [Since they were unable...CH]
Gu Sou also invited Shun to drink wine with him
so that when he got drunk, they could kill him.
When Shun informed the two daughters
they gave him some medicine and had him wash in the Zhou pool.
Thereupon he set out
and drank wine the whole day, but did not become drunk.
The younger sister of Shun [Guo Shou] pitied him
and was in sympathy with her two sisters-in-law.
Though his father and mother wished to kill him
he still would not harbor a grudge against them
indefinitely. [??????? CH]
and wept and cried
before the distant heavens.
He called out the names of his father and mother;
and in spite of their harming him,
he respected them very much.
He bore no grievance against his younger brother
but was sincere and generous [with him].
When he was made a prime minister
and had guests coming to him from all directions,
Yao sent him into the forests
and into the copses on the slopes of the hills.
Though Yao tried him by a hundred methods
he always planned each affair with the two daughters [of Yao].
When Shun succeeded to his [Yao's] place,
he was elevated to become the Son of Heaven.
E Huang became Quen,
and Nyu Ying became the royal Wife.
He granted Xiang a fief in You Bei,
and served Gu Sou as before.
Everyone called the two royal Wives intelligent, chaste, and benevolent.
Shun, while hunting,
died at Cang Wu, [a mountainin Hunan].
His honorary title was "Chong Hua."
The two royal Wives died in the region betgween the chiang [Yangtze] and the Xiang rivers,
and therefore they were commonly called the "Ladies of the Xiang."
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
The two royal Wives were virtuous, guileless, and acted sincerely." [de: inner qualities CH]
The Book of Songs says:
Nothing so glorious as their power,
all princes imitate them.
This it says of them.
The Song says:
In the beginning the two Royal wives
were the daughters of the Lord Yao.
They became the wives of You Yyu.
They followed Shun obediently
and used nobility to serve the humble.
To the last they were able to undertake tiresome labor.
They conciliated "Gu Sou"
and in the end enjoyed happiness and blessings.
JIANG YUAN, THE MOTHER OF QI
Jiang Yuan, the mother of Qi,
was the daughter of the marquis of Tai.
In the time of Lord Yao
she went out to see the footsteps of a giant,
took a fancy to them, trod in them,
and when she returned [home] she became pregnant.
gradually becoming larger.
Since she shought it strange and disliked it,
she divined and offered a pure sacrifice
that she might be childless.
At last she gave birth to a child,
but considering it unlucky abandoned it in a narrow lane.
Cattle and sheep avoided it and did not step on it.
Then she took it to the middle of a forest on the plains.
Later [woodcutters] who were cutting down the forest covered it with mats.
Then she took it and placed it on the cold ice,
but the birds covered it round with their wings.
Jiang Yuan, thinking this extraordinary,
took the child up to return [home].
Because of his fate, she gave him the name Qi "Abandoned".
The disposition of Chiang Yyuan
was mild, tranquil, and of a single purpose.
She liked to sow, cultivate, and harvest.
When her son grew up,
she taught him to plant trees - the mulberry and hemp. [shù "to plant"]
His disposition was intelligent and benevolent,
and he could cultivate his mother's teachings.
In the end he attained his fame.
[Lord] Yao ordered Qi to fill the office of Minister of Agriculture.
He raised Tai to a kingdom
and enfeoffed Qi in Tai.
He was given the honorary title, "Hou Ji" or God of Agriculture.
When the Lord yao died,
and Shun ascended the throne,
he ordered him [Qi],
"Qi!
The common people suffer from hunger;
you, the Minister of Agriculture,
sow all kinds of grain in their season."
Afterwards his posterity from generation to generation filled the office of Minister of Agricultrure
until Wen and Wu of Zhou rose to be Sons of Heaven.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
Jiang Yuan was mild and transformed others.
The Book of Songs says:
"Glorious was Jiang Yyuan,
Her power was without flaw.
God on high succoured her."
It also says:
"Mighty are you, Hou Ji,
Full partner in heaven's power.
That we, the thronging peoples were raised up
This it says of them.
The Song says:
Jiang Yuan, the mother of Qi,
was pure, mild, and single-minded.
She stepped in the footprints[of a giant] and conceived [a child].
Overcome with fear, she abandoned it in the wilderness,
but the birds and animals protected and brooded over it.
Then she returned to take it up compassionately.
In the end he became the assistant of the ruler
and she fulfilled he motherly duty.
JIAN DI, THE MOTHER OF XIE
Jian Di, the mother of Xie,
was the eldest daughter of a family in the Kingdom of Song.
This was in the time of Lord Yao. Once as she was bathing with her her younger sisters in the waters at Xuanqiu
a swallow carrying an egg in its bill
went over them and dropped it.
Pleased with its variegated color,
Jian Di and her sisters vied with each other to run and get it.
Jian Di obtained it, held it in her mouth,
and accidentally swallowed it.
Whereupon she gave birth to Xie.
By nature she was good at managing human affairs;
she was more than ordinarily acquainted with astronomy, and took pleasure in manifesting charity [to others]"
As Xie grew up, she taught him the principles and order of relationships.
His disposition was clever and benevolent
and he could cultivate her teachings.
In the end he attained his fame.
[Lord] Yao made him Minister of Education
and enfeoffed him at Bo.
After Yao had died and Shun had ascended the Throne,
he commanded him saying,
"Xiu, the people continue unfriendly with one another,
and do not observe with docility the five orders of relations.
It is yours, as Minister of Instruction, reverently to set forth the lessons of duty belonging to those five orders. Do so with gentleness."
His posterity resided at Bo until Tang of Yin rose up as Son of Heaven.
Chien Ti was benevolent and possessed propriety.
The book of Songs says:
"The clan of Song was favoured; / God appointed its child to bear Shang."
It also says:
"Heaven bade the dark bird
to come down and bear the Shang."
This is to say of her.
The Song says:
Chien Ti, the mother of Xie, was simple,
benevolent, stern, and vigorous in service.
She swallowed an egg an gave birth to a child.
Thereafter she cultivated and adorned herself.
She taught by using the principles of actions,
extended her kindness to others, and possessed virtue.
Xie's becoming the Assistant of the ruler
was probably a result of his mother's effort.
TU SHAN, THE MOTHER OF CHI
The mother of Qi
was the eldest daughter in the family of Tu Shan.
Yu of the Xia dynasty married her, making her Royal Consort
and thereafter she gave birth to Ji.
For [the four days] Xin, Ren, Kui, and Jia
Qi wailed and wept,
for Yu had gone to direct the course of the floods,
and planned with all his might his labor on the land.
Three times he passed his home
but did not enter its door.
Though she was alone, Tu Shan knew how to teach
and brought about her son's transformation.
and as Qi grew up,
he was fashioned by her virtue and followed her teachings.
At last he attained to an honorable fame
and when Yu became Son of Heaven,
Qi was his heir.
He maintained Yu's merit and did not fail.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Du Shan was energetic in giving instruction.
The book of Songs says:
"He gives to you a girl,- 6 -
That you may in due time have grandsons and sons."
This it says of her.
The Song says:
Tu Shan, the mother of Qi,
was wedded to Lord Yu
but after [the four days] Xin, Ren, Kui, and Jia,
Yu went to manage the floods.
Ji wailed and cried.
His mother alone taught him the right order and precedence in human relationships.
She instructed him to be good
and in the end he succeeded his father.
YU SHEN, THE ROYAL WIFE OF TANG
Yu Shen, the Royal Wife of Tang, was a daughter of a family of the kingdom of Yu Shen.
Tang of the Yin dynasty took her in marriage as his Royal Wife
and she gave birth to Rong Ren and Wai Bing.
They also understood her teaching
and her training, and attained her merit.
This was Yu Wen, the Royal Wife of Tang.
She had general control over the ruler's concubines,
saw to it that the inner apartments of the Palace had order,
and that there were no envious, flattering, or unprincipled persons there.
In the end she attained regal glory.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Royal Wife wife was intelligent and orderly.
The Book of Songs says:
"Lovely is this noble lady, /
Fit bride for our lord."
It speaks of the virtous woman who was able to bring harmony among all the concubines.
This could be said of You Xin.
The Song says:
the wife of Tang, You Xin,
was a woman of virtuous conduct and intelligent.
As a maid servant of I Yin [Tang's minister]
she had accompanied him from a kingdom in Xia in Shang.
She was diligent and faithful in ruling the inner departments
so that the Royal Concubines had good deportments.
She transformed and taught both those in the Palace and those outside,
and this moreover without failure [in the manner of doing it] and without offense [to others]
THE THREE MOTHERS OF THE CHOU FAMILY
The three mothers
were Tai Jiang, Tai Ren, and Tai Si.
Tai Jiang
was the mother of Wang Ji
and the daughter of the You family.
King Tai took her as his Royal Wife
and she gave birth to Tai Bo, Zhong Yong and Wang Ji.
She was chaste and docile in directing [her sons]
and was wihout faults.
If King Tai planned a matter
or moved about,
it must be with Tai Jiang.
The man of noble Sentiments says: Tai Jiang was great in virtous teaching.
Tai Ren
was the mother of the Acomplished King [Wen Wang]
and the second daughter of the Zhi Ren clan.
Wang Ji took her in marriage as Royal Wife.
Tai Ren's position was upright, sincere, decorous,
and engaged solely in virtous conduct.
When she was with child,
her eyes would not gaze on evil things;
her ears would not listen to lewd sounds;
and her mouth would not emit insolent words.
She was capable in prenatal instruction.
She gave birth to the Accomplished King
as she was about to urinate in the pigsty.
The accomplished king grew up and became an illustrious sage.
Tai Ren taught him one thing
and [from that] he comprehended a hundred others.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Tai Ren was capable in prenatal instruction.
In ancient times, a woman with child
did not lie on her side as she slept;
neither would she sit sidewise
not stand on foot.
She would not eat dishes- 8 -having harmful flavors;
if the food was cut awry, whe could not eat it;
if the mat was not placed straight, she would not sit on it.
She did not let her eyes gaze on lewd sights
nor let her ears listen to depraved sounds.
At night she ordered the blind musicians to chant poetry.
She used right reason to adjust affairs,
and thus
gave birth to children of correct physical form
who excelled others in talent and virtue.
For this reason a woman with child
should be careful about things that affect them.
If she is affected by good things, the child will be good.
if she is affected by evil things, the child will be evil.
Men resemble the natural order
because their mothers were influenced by that order.
For that reason their features and sounds correspond to it.
the Acomplished King's mother may be said to have known to make her childs conform to it.
Tai Si was
the mother of the Martial King
and the daughter of the Si clan, a descendant of the great Yu and a native of the kingdom of Xin.
She was a compassionate and understood what was right.
the accomplished King was pleased with her
and went in person to welcome her at the River Wei
where he built a bridge of boats [to lead her across].
When she entered [the palace],
Tai Si thought highly of Tai Jiang and Tai Ren.
From early dawn to late at night,
she toiled diligently and thus fulfilled her role as wife.
Tai Wi was given th honorary title of "Wen Mu" {Mother of the Accomplished King].
The Accomplished King governed external affairs
and "Wen Mu" ruled inside the Palace.
Tai Si gave birth to ten sons:
the eldest was Bo I Kao, the others Wu Wang Fa, Zhou Gong Dan, Guan Shu Xian, Cai Shu Du, Cao Shu Zhenduo, Huo Shu Wu, Cheng Shu Chu, Kang Shu Feng, and Ran Ji Zai.
Tai Si diligently instructed her ten sons
so that from the time they were small until they grew up,
they never looked on harmful or mean things.
And after they grew up,
the Accomplished King continued to instructed them,
thus being finally successul in bringing out the virtues of the Martial King [Wu Wang] and the Duke of Zhou.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Tai Si was benevolent, intelligent,- 9 -and possessed virtues.
The book of Songs says:
"A great country had a child /
Fair as a sister of Heaven. /
King Wen fixed on a lucky day /
and went himself to meet her at the Wei; /
He joined boats and made of them a bridge; /
Very dazzling their splendour." /
It also says:
"And Tai Si carried on her name,
Bearing a multitude of sons." /
This it says of her.
The Sung says:
The three mothers of the Zhou family
were Tai Jiang, Tai Ren, and Tai Si.
The rise of Wen and Wu
took their start from them.
Being the most virtous,
Tai Si was given the title of "Wen Mu."
But the virtue of all three women
was very great.
Ding Jiang, a Maiden of Wei
Ding Jiang, a maiden of the kingdom of Wei,
was the wife of Duke Ding of Wei
and the mother of Gong Zi.
Gong Zi had no sooner married than he died,
leaving his wife childless.
After she [i.e., Ding Jiang] had completed three years of mourning,
she returned to her own home,
her daughter-in-law escorting her
back to the country.
As [the daughter in law] loved her fondly and sadly called up memories of her,
her heart was sorrowful and her affections were disturbed.
As she looked at her mother-in-law,
she brushed away the falling tears
and composed a prose-poem as follows:
"Swallow, swallow, on your flight, //
Wing high, wing low. //
Our lady that goes home, //
Far we escort beyond the fields. //
Gaze after her, cannot see her, //
And our tears flow like rain," //
She accompanied her, returned weeping, and gazed after her.
Then she also composed a poem as follows:
"Mindful of her late lord, //
Making provision for his helpless ones, " //
The Man of Noble sentiments says: Ding Jiang was a kind mother-in-law. She was excessive in her generosity.
Since duke Ding hated Sun Lin-fu,
Sun Lin-fu fled to the country of Jin
The Marquis of Jin sent Jue Qi too ask that he be allowed to return
but Duke Ding wished to refuse.
Then Ding Jiang said,
"You cannot refuse this,- 10 -
for he is the heir of the clan-official of our former ruler.
The great state, [Jin] moreover, has requested i
and you have not granted its request.
We are about to perish.
Althought you hate him [Sun Lin-fu]
is it not better to receive him back than to perish?
My lord, bear with him.
Now if the people are at peace and you forgive the clan-official,
is not that all right?"
Duke Ding thereupon restored him.
The man of noble Sentiments says: Ding Jiang was able to keep calamity at a distance.
The book of Songs says:
"Their ways are faultless, //
They shape our land from end to end. //
This could be said of her.
When Duke Ding died,
they established as ruler Kan, his son by Jing-si,
who became Duke Xien
In performing his mourning, Duke Xien was indifferent.
While Ding Jiang was weeping and sighing,
she noticed that Duke Xien was not sorrowing.
She did not take food or drink
and sighed, saying:
"This one will ruin the Kingdom of Wei.
First he will injure virtuous men
and then Heaven will send calamities on the kingdom.
Now, I was not able to bring it about that Zhuan should preside over the country's altars."
When the high officials heard this, they all feared
and from this time Sun Wenzi did not dare to leave his article of value in the state of Wei.
Zhuan
was Zixian, the younger brother of Duke Xian.
As he was capable,
Ding Jiang had wished to establish him as ruler but had not obtained it.
Later Duke Xian, who was cruel and violent,
treated Ding Jiang contemptuously.
In the end, he was driven from the country.
In fleeing, when he reached the boundaries of the state,
he ordered sacrifices to be offered in the ancestral temple
to announce his flight and to proclaim that he was without guilt.
Ding Jiang said,
"This cannot be done.
If there be no spirits, why inform them?
If there be spirits, they are not imposed upon.
Guilty as he is,
how can he say that he is free from guilt?
Moreover, his conduct
in passing over the higher officials to consult with the lower former ones
is one act of guilt.
He disgraced
the chief minister of the former ruler [his father] who had been appointed as tutor to him.
That was the second act of guilt.
He was oppressive,
as to a concubine, to me who with towel and comb served his father.
That was the third act of guilt.
Proclaim his flight and nothing more.
Do not proclaim that he had no guilt!"
Afterwards by relying on the power of Zhuan,
Duke Xien again recovered his rebellious state.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Ding Jiang was able to use her eloquence to teach others.
The Books of Songs says;
"My words are about [the present urgent] affairs."
This could be said of her.
Huang-er of the state of Zheng led troops to invade Wei.
Sun Wen-zu- 11 - divined to see if he should pursue them.
He presented the prognostication to Ding Jiang, saying,
"The indication is like a hill;
a party goes forth on an expedition and loses its leader."
Ding Jiang observed,
"The invaders lose their leader;
this is favorable to those who resist them.
You, the minister, take measures accordingly."
The men of Wei pursued the enemy
and captured Huang-er at Quan Qiu.
The man of noble sentiments says: Ding Jiang thoroughly understood matters.
The Books of Songs says:
"Put them to the left, to the left, /
And the gentlemen do what is best." /
This could be said of her.
The Sung says:
Ding Jiang, a Maiden of Wey, accompanied the wife
and spoke to her in poetry.
She was merciful, loving, motherly, and benevolent.
As she wept, she gazed at her.
After she had admonished Duke Xian several times,
she suffered wrongs and dislike from him.
She was intelligent and farsighted in her knowledge;
her literary expressions were elegant.
THE GOVERNESS OF THE LADY OF QI
The governess
was the governess of the Lady of Qi
who was the wife of Duke Zhuang of Wei.
Her [the wife's] honorary title was "Zhuang Jiang"
Zhiang was very pretty.
When she first went to her husband's home,
her moderation lessened and her deportment became too free.
She had the conduct of courtesan
and a heart of liciousness.
The governess, seeing that her wifely principles were wrong,
spoke to her saying,
"Your family
for generations has been honored and respected
so that it has become an example for the people;
your talent
is cleverness at seeing through matters
so that you should be a model for others.
If your outer appearance is resplendent and beautiful,
you must cultivate virtue and be proper.
to put on a single garment over an embroidered robe
was an adornment for travel in chariots and horses;
it was not to honor virtue."
Then she composed a poem, saying:
"A splendid woman and upstanding; /
Brocade she wore, over an unlined coat, /
Daughter of the Lord of Qi, /
Wife of the Lord of Wei, /
Sister of the Crown Prince of Qi, /
Called sister-in-law by the Lord of Xing
Calling the Lord of Tan her brother-in-law. /
She should discipline her womanly heart in order to exalt her chastity
and treat the juniors of the Ruler as men.
Since she is the wife of the ruler of the state,
it is all the more forbidden to her to manifest depraved conduct."
Thereafter the lady [of Qi] was moved and corrected her conduct.
The man of Noble Sentiments praised the Governess for taking precautions before the evil arrival.
Zhuang Jiang
was the younger sister of Teh-zhen, the heirson [of Qi]
As she was childless,
she took care of Duke Huan, son of Tai Gui, as if he were her own.
The Duke's son, Zhouyu[I.H. Xu!]was the son of [another] concubine.
He had the favor [of the Duke],
was self-confident, and liked military pursuits.
Duke Zhuang did not forbid them to him
and later Zhouyu really killed [his own brother], Duke Huan.
The book of Songs says,
"Do not teach a monkey to climb trees."
This could be said of him.
The Sung says:
The Governess of the Lady of Qi
corrected the Lady before the evil was at hand.
She enumerated all her ancestors
of whom there was no one without honor and glory.
She wrote a poem clearly pointing this out
so that she would not disgrace her ancestors.
In the end, Zhuang Jiang, as foster mother and younger sister,
was able to act properly.
JING JIANG
Jing Jiang nee Ji of Lu
was a woman of Ju
whose honorary title was "Tai Ji"
She was the wife of Gongfu Mubo,
the mother of Wenbo, and the paternal grandaunt of Ji Kangzu.
Her knowledge was extensive and she was well versed in propriety.
Though Mubo died early,
Jing Jiang preserved a rightous way of life.
Wenbo went outside to study and then returned.
Jing Jiang watched him without appearing to do so.
She saw his friends enter the hall,
descend from the back steps, and stop.
They presented his sword, and straightened his shoe laces
as if they were serving their fathers or elder brothers.
Wenbo considered himself as a grown man.
Jing Jiang summoned him and reprimanded him, saying,
"In ancient times, King Wu dismissed his court
and would tie up his stocking that had broken.- 13 -
The bystanders looked on but there was no one of them whom he could order to tie it
so he leaned over and tied it himself.
For this reason he was able to perfect the kingly way.
Duke Han had three friends who sat in his presence;
he had an advisory council of five;
and there were thirty men to bring up whatever mistakes he made each day.
For this reason he was able to accomplish his career as a prince.
The Duke of Zhou during one meal interrupted his eating three times;
in washing, put up his hair three times
when he had to greet those bringing presents; and interviewed more than seventy men from the poor alley-ways.
For this reason he was able to keep alive the Family of Zhou.
These two wise men and the one of ability
all became leaders of the feudal princes.
While they condescended to men in this manner,
they travelled about with those
who were all better than themselves
and thus improved themselves each day without knowing it.
Now, you who at present are young and whose position is low,
go around with friends
who subsequently wait on you.
It is obvious
that you do not profit from them."
Wenbo then acknowledged his fault
and thereupon chose a strict teacher and talented friends whom he served.
The ones who travelled and lived with him were all old men or very young men.
Wenbo brought forward the mats, rolled up the scrolls, personally served the food to them.
Jing Jiang said,
"Now you are a mature man."
The Man of the Noble Sentiments says: Jing Jiang was perfect in transforming others.
The Book of Songs says,
""Splendid were those many knights /
Who gave comfort to Wen the King. /
This could be said of her.
When Wenbo was minister of Lu,
Jing Jiang spoke to him, saying
"I shall tell you
what is important in ruling the country
and how to be perfect in managing others.
What is a measuring stick?
Whatsoever makes straight the crooked and rights wrong.
He cannot help but be strong
and for this reason, such a one should be a general.
What is a plan?
Whatsoever adjust what is ill-fitting and causes those who are disobedient to obey.
For this reason the one who plans, can be the chief magistrate - 14 -
What is the matter?
Whatsoever can rule silk fiber and the matter between the skin and the flesh.
For this reason the one who is like matter can be the prefect of the capital.
That which has the ability to hold on to communicating objects without losing them
and to things coming and going without breaking them,
is a shuttle.
Such a one can become the member of a great guild.
The one who pushes and it goes
and who pulls and it comes,
is a weaver.
Such a one can become Master of the Visiting Gate.
The one who masters more or less of numbers,
is an equalizer.
Such a one can become the annalist of the kingcom.
That which can fill an important position,
can travel a long way,
and be upright and firm,
is an axis.
The axis can be used as a minister.
To expand and that endlessly,
is to excel.
The one who excelscan be used as San Gong."
Wenbo continued to honor her by hearing her instruction.
Wenbo left the court
and went again to see Jing Jiang
who was spinning thread just then.
Wenbo said,
"In the house of Chu,
you, the mistress, are still spinning thread.
I fear that you will provoke the anger of Ji Sun
who will think that Chu cannot provide for the Mistress of the house."
Jing Jiang sighed and said,
"Shall the Kingdom of Lu go to ruin now?
They order boys to fill the posts of officials when they have not yet learned how to do so.
Remain here
and I shall speak with you.
Formerly the virtous kings managed the people as follows:
they selected poor land and dwelt there;
they gave the people work and used them.
For this reason they long ruled the nation.
When the people were employed,
they reflected,- 15 -
and goodness were born in their hearts.
If they enjoyed ease, then they became licentious.
Those who were licentious, forgot goodness
and when they forgot goodness, then evil was born in their hearts.
The people of fertile lands are not talented;
they are licentious.
The people of poor lands tend toward righteousness;
they are employed.
For this reason, the ruler used his most beautiful robes for the spring solstice sacrifice in the morning
with the three highest officials and nine ministers. They have long known quality of the land.
At noon he examined the government
with a hundred officers of government affairs.
He ordered the leaders and chiefs to meet with the soldiers and shephers to announce and arrange the peple's affairs.
He used the more somber robes for the autumn solstice sacrifice in the evening
and examined the royal punishments with the recorders and astronomers.
At sunset he examined the nine ministers
and ordered them to cleanse the instruments used in the suburban sacrifices;
afterwards they retired.
In the morning the nobles learned the ordinations of the ruler;
at noon they examined the government;
and in the evening they looked into the laws and punishments.
At night they exhorted the craftsmen
to prevent insolence and dissoluteness
and afterwards they retired.
The courtiers in the morning examined their duties;
during the day they discussed public affairs;
in the evening they planned their business;
and at night they regulated their home affairs.
Afterwards they retired.
The scholars in the morning received their instructions,
during the day they taught their subordinates;
and they practiced them again in the evening.
At night they relentlessly
investigated their mistakes
and afterwards they retired.
From the common people on down
in the morning they started their work
and in the evening they stopped
without giving themselves up to idleness.
"The queen, herself wove the first silk fringe for the crown;
the wives of nobles added to it the cord to go under the chin and the pendants for gems;
and the wife of the prime minister made the large sash.
The wives of the officials of lower rank made the sacrificial robes
and the wives of the scholars added to it the court clothes.
all [of the wives] clothed their husbands.
They sacrificed to the protective spirits and tended to their business.
They cooked meals and exhibited their results.
Both men and women produced meritorious achievements.
If they did not conform the pattern, they were punished.
such was the government of the ancients.
The prince exerted his intellectual powers
and the people exerted their physical strength.
This was the teaching of the early kings.
From the superior down to the inferior,
who was there who dared to give his heart up to licentiousness and not to use his strength?
Today, I am a widow
and you are in a lowly position as yet;
from morning until evening we are occupied with business
and yet fearful of forgetting the career of our forefathers.
Moreover when there are indolent ones [in our own family],
how can we avoid them?
I desire that from morning until evening you [labor at] perfecting yourself.
I say: Let us not cast aside the achievements of our ancestors.
Will you now say, 'Why should not I myself be in peace?'
If you continue to perform your official duty with such an idea,
I am afraid that the posterity of Mubo will come to an end."
Zhongni upon hearing this, said,
"Disciples, remember this!"
The wife of the Chi Family was not licentious.
The Book of Songs says:
"So a woman who has nothing to do with public affairs, //
Leaves her silk worms and weaving." //
This is to say that a woman's public office is her weaving and spinning.
If she stops it, that is not proper.
Wenbo gave a banquet in the South Palace in honor of his paternal uncle
and he had Lu Dufu as a guest.
When he presented the turtles that were small,
Dufu was angry.
The minister invited him to eat the turtles
and Dufu refused saying,
"Let the turtles grow up and then I will eat them."
Then he went out.
Jing Jiang heard this
and she angrily said,
"I have heard that my ancestors said
that a sacrifice provides for a dead body;
a banquet is given honored guests.
What propriety is there in offering a turtle to a man?
Now you have made me angry."
Then she drove Wenbo out of the house.
After five days,
the Duchess of Lu spoke for him and he returned.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Jing Jiang was careful of minute details.
The Book of Songs says:
"I have good wine; //
Let my lucky guest now feast and play." //
It spoke of honored guests.
When Wenbo died,
Jing Jiang cautioned his concubines, saying,
"I have heard this:
he who loves the women of the house too much,
dies on that account.
He who likes the scholars from outside,
dies on that account.
Today, my son has died an untimely death.
I dislike the rumor that he has loved the women of the house too much
and the disgrace of several wives
offering the sacrifices to the ancestors.
I ask you not to remove your adornments
nor to wipe away your tears.
Do not strike your breasts - 17 -
nor have a mournful appearance.
If you have decreased your mourning clothes,
do not add mourning clothes
but follow the rites and be quiet.
This makes illustrious my son."
Zhongni upon hearing this said,
"The woman knows nothing better than being a wife;
The man knows nothing better than being a husband.
Such was the knowledge of the wife of the Gongfu Family.
She wished to make illustrious the shining virtue of her son."
The Book of Songs says:
"Our lord shall have corn //
to give his grandsons and sons." //
This might be said of him.
While Jing Jiang was living in mourning,
in the morning she wept for Mubo
and in the evenng she cried for Wenbo.
Zhongni heard of this and said,"
The wife of the Ji clan can be said to have understood ceremonies
and her love was without self-seeking.
Superior and inferior have their regulations."
Jing Jiang had returned to the Ji clan.
While Kangzi was at court,
he spoke to her
but she did not answer.
He followed her
even to the door of her dwelling,
but she did not answer and entered.
Kangzi excused himself at court
and entered to see her, saying,
"I, Fei, did not hear your order.
Could there be any offense then?
Jing Jiang replied,
"Have you not learned
that the ruler plans with the feudal princes the people's business in the outer court and the business of the gods in the inner court?
From the prime minister on down, they plan their official duties in the outer court
and their family affairs in the inner court.
Within,
it is the province of women to preside ofer their official duties.
Superior and inferior are alike in this
for in the outer court you care for the duties of the princely profession
and in the inner court you regulate the affairs of the Ji household.
In all of these matters, it is not I who would dare to speak."
Kangzi attempted to come up with her.
She opened the door a little and spoke with him
but no one was to pass the threshold.
She sacrificed and mourned for her son
while Kangzi assisted at the sacrifice.
The pledge offering of wine, she could not bear to return;
sacrificial dishes were not meant for a clan banquet.
If all was not completely arranged, she did not sacrifice.
If she sacrificed, she did not drink all the offering of wine and then withdrew.
Zhongni said, "Jing Jiang distinguished between the ceremonies for men and for women."
The Book of Songs says,
"It was not I who was at fault." //
The Sung says:
The mother of Wenbo
had as her honorary title, "Jing Jiang."
She thoroughly understood the rules of propriety
and her virtous conduct was illustrious.
She corrected her son's faults
and taught him by laws and principles.
Zhongni called her talented.
She was distinguished by the title of "Kind Mother."
THE MOTHER OF ZI FA OF CHU
She was the mother of Zi Fa, a general of Chu.
While Zi Fa was carrying on a campaign against the kingdom of Qin, his grain supply ran out.
He sent a messenger to the King of Chu to ask for help
and and on the occasion of his return to ask about his [the general's] mother's welfare.
His mother inquired of the messenger,
"Have the soldiers kept good health?"
He replied,
"The soldiers have divided equally among themselves beans and pulse and have eaten it."
She also asked
if the general of the army were in good health.
He replied,
"Each morning and evening the general had chicken, pork, corn, and millet"
When Zi Fa had defeated Qin and returned home,
his mother closed the door [of her home] and would not receive him.
She sent a messenger to reprimand him, saying,
"Did you not hear what King Kou Jian of Yue [did] when he was campaigning against the state of Wu?
When a guest presented him with a bottle of good wine,
the king sent a man to pour it into the river upstream
and ordered his men to drink downstream.
Its taste did not equal the hapiness it gave [to the men],
Another day someone offered the king a bag of dry rations.
The king bestowed it all on the soldiers
who divided it and ate it.
Although its sweetness scarcely touched their palates,
the soldiers fought each as ten men.
Now, while you were general,
the men divided each bean and ate it,
but you alone, morning and evening, dined on domestic animals, corn, and millet.
How was that?
Does the poem not say,
'Amuse yourselves, but no wildness! //
Good men are always demure.' //
It says that one should not lose his moral equity.
You sent your men to enter the dangers of the battlefield
while you yourself took your pleasure and repose above them.
Although you have won the victory,
it was not by your strategy.
You are my son.
do not enter my door!"
Zi Fa begged his mother's pardon
and afterwards she admitted him [to her home].
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The mother of Zi Fa was able to instruct people.
The Book of Songs says:
" Teach and train your sons, //
and they will become good as you are." //
This could be said of her.
The Sung says:
The mother of Zi Fa
criticized her son's pride and laziness.
While the general had corn and millet,
the soldiers had beans and pulse.
She reproved his lack of propriety
for thus he could not obtain men's help.
The Man of Noble Sentiments praised her.
[Her story] is recorded as the Mother's Virtue.
THE MOTHER OF MENG KE OF ZOU
She was the mother of Meng Ke of Zou;
her honorary title was "Meng Mu".
She was living near a graveyard
when Mengzi was small
and he enjoyed going out to play as if he were working among the graves.
He enthusiastically built up the graves and performed burials.
His mother said
"This is not the place for me to keep my son."
Then she departed and dwelt beside a market place.
Since he enjoyed playing as if his business were that of the merchant and bargainer,
his mother again said,
"This is not the place for me to live with my son."
She once more moved her abode and dwelt beside a schoolhouse.
He [Megzi] amused himself by setting up the instruments of worship and by bowing politely to those coming and going.
Meng Mu said,
"Truly my son can dwell here."
Thereafter they dwelt there
and as Mengzi grew up
he learned the six liberal arts.
In the end he attained fame as a great scholar.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Meng Mu was able to improve others gradually.
The Book of Songs says:
"That admirable gentleman, - //
What will he give them [for this] //
This could be applied here.
While Mengzi was young yet,
he was studying at school.
When he returned home, Meng Mu, who was weaving,
asked him, saying,
"How much have you learned?"
Mengzi said,
"About as usual."
Meng Mu took up a knife and cut the web of her loom.
Mengzi was frightened and asked the reason for her doing that.
Meng Mu said,
"Your being remiss in your studies
is like my cutting the web of my loom.
Now the Superior Man learns that he may establish a reputation;
he investigates that he may broaden his knowledge
Therefore if you remain inactive, you will be peaceful;
if you arouse yourself, you will keep harm away.
If you now abandon your studies,
you will not avoid becoming a privy servant
and will be without means of freeing yourself from your misfortune.
What difference is there [in your studying] and my weaving? I spin thread that we may have food.
If the woman abandons her weaving when she is half way through,
how shall she clothe her husband
and how shall he grow without grain to eat?
Just as the woman who abandons what she has to eat,
so the man who fails in his cultivation of virtue,
if he does not become a thief or robber,
will become a captive or a slave."
Mengzi, having become frightened,
studied diligently morning and evening without respite.
He served his teacher, Zi Si,
and consequently became the famous scholar of the whole nation.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Meng Mu knew the role of a man's mother.- 21 -
The Book of Songs says:
"The admirable gentleman, -
What will he tell him?"
This could be applied here.
After Megzi had married,
he was about to enter [his wife's] private room
and saw her disrobed within.
As Mengzi was displeased,
he immediately departed without entering.
His wife apologized to Meng Mu and asked to depart.
She said,
"I have learned about the state of matrimony
and it does not include [the sharing of] one's private room.
Today when I secretely yielded to laziness in my own room,
my husband saw me.
At once he became displeased
and treated me as a guest concubine.
The rules of conduct of the wife demand
that she not stay over night as a guest.
I ask to return to my father and mother."
For this reason, Meng Mu summoned her son and said to him,
"It is proper etiquette
that when one is about to enter a door
to ask who is within
and thus on attains to proper respect.
When one is about to enter a hall,
he should raise his voice so
as to warn those within.
If one is about to enter the door of a room,
the glance should be cast down,
lest one see another's fault.
Today you did not observe the rules of etiquette
and yet you found fault with the etiquette of your wife.
Are you not far from right conduct?"
Mengzi thanked her
and retained his wife.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Meng Mu understood propriety
and the duty of a mother-in-law
While Mengzi was living in Qi,
he had an air of sadness about him.
Meng Mu noticed it and said,
"Son, how is it
that you have an air of sadness about you?"
Mengzi replied,
"I have not."
Another day when at leisure at home,
he was leaning against a pillar and sighing.
Meng Mu saw him and said,
"The other day you seemed to have a sad appearance
but you said you were not sad.
Today you are leaning against a pillar and sighing.
Why are you doing that?"
Mengzi replied,
"I, Ke,
have learned that the Superior Man is first qualified and then receives his position.
He does not attempt to attain it unfairly and then receive a reward
nor does he covet honors and emoluments.
If the nobles do not listen,
he does not force himself upon his superiors;
if they listen to his teachings but do not follow him,
then he does not set foot in their court.
Today, the Tao is not followed in the state of Qi
and I desire to depart but my mother is old.
That is why I am sad."
Meng Mu said,
"Now the proper conduct of a woman
is found in her skill in preparing the five foods,
fermenting the wine,
caring for her husband's parents,
and making clothes and that is all.
A woman's duty is to care for the household- 22 -
and she should have no desire to go abroad.
The Book of Changes says,
'She provides sustenance
and avoids going out.'
The Book of Songs says;
" 'For her no decorations, no emblems; //
Her only care the wine and food.' //
This means that it does not belong to the woman to determine anything herself
but she has the three obediences.
xxxx
Therefore, when young, she has to obey her parents;
when married, she has to obey her husband;
when her husband is dead, she obeys her son.
This is proper etiquette.
Now my son has reached maturity
and I am old.
Do you act acording to righteousness
and I shall act according to the rules of propriety."
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Meng Mu knew the duties of a woman.
The Book of Songs says:
" He glances, he smiles, //
Very patiently he teaches us. //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The mother of Meng Ke
influenced by her teaching in every detail.
By choosing her son's dwelling place she chose the liberal arts for him.
She caused him to follow the social relationships.
When her son's learning did not advance,
she made him understand [its importance] by cutting the web of her loom.
The son thereafter perfected his virtue
and became the most honored person of his generation.
THE MOTHER TEACHER OF THE STATE OF LU
The Mother Teacher
was the widowed mother of nine sons of the state of Lu.
On the day of the winter sacrifice,
after the returned workers had duly performed the annual sacrifices and ceremonies,
she summoned all her sons
and spoke to them saying,
"The right conduct of a woman requires that
unless there is great reason,
she could not go out of her husband's house.
On the other hand, since my parent's home has many young and tender ones
who do not know how to perform the annual sacrifies,
I would obey you in asking leave to go and supervise them."
The sons all bowed their heads and permitted [her to go].
Then again she summoned all the wives [of the sons] and said,
"A woman has the duty of the three obediences
and she is allowed no actions of complete authority.
When she is young, she is bound to her father and mother;
when she grows up, she is bound to her husband;
and when she is old, she is bound to her sons.
Today, all my sons have permitted me to return to see my family.
If this exceeds proper etiquette,- 23 -
I desire my youngest son to go with me
in order to follow the resrictions on a woman's coming and going.
You, wives, carefully guard the household door
and this evening I shall return."
On this account, she ordered the young children and servants
to return and attend to their housework.
Since the sky was overcast, she returned too early.
When she arrived outside the village gate, she stopped there
and when it was evening she entered.
The minister of Lu saw this from his terrace and wondered about it.
He sent men secretely to watch the home
and they saw that the festival rites were well cared for
and that the household affairs were well regulated.
The messengers returned and made their report.
Thereupon the minister of Lu summoned the mother and asked her, saying,
"One day when you came from the north,
upon reaching the village gate, you stopped for a long time
and after it was evening, you entered.
I did not understand the reason for you doing so.
Since I wondered greatly about it,
I am asking about it.
The mother replied,
"I unfortunately
lost my husband early in life
and I am living alone with my nine sons.
On the day of the winter sacrifice,
as the ceremonies were completed and the work was done,
under obedience to all my sons I went back to see my family.
I told the wives and children
that I should return in the evening
for I feared that they would be eating and drinking freely
since men's actions are such.
I returned too early
and did not dare go back again.
I stopped at the village gate
and when the time had come, I entered."
The minister of Lu praised her
and spoke of her to Duke Mu
who awarded her the honored title of the "Mother Teacher."
He sent an invitation to his wife [to come].
His wife and all the concubines took her as their teacher.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Mother Teacher was able to instruct by her example.
This is propriety:
If a woman is not married,
she regards her father and mother as heaven.
When she marries,
she considers her husband as heaven.
When she mourns her father and mother,
she lowers her mourning for them one degree.
This is the principle of not having two masters.
The Book of Songs says
"On the journey you will lodge at Zi,
You will drink the cup of parting at Ni,
A girl that goes to be married,
This could be said of her.- 24 -
THE INDULGENT MOTHER OF THE MANG [FAMILY] OF WEI
The indulgent Mother of the Mang [Family] of Wei
the daughter of the Meng Yang Family of Wei
and the second wife of Mang Mao
While she had three sons,
the first wife's sons numbered five,
none of which liked her.
The Indulgent Mother treated them very kindly
and yet they did not love her.
The Indulgent Mother then ordered her three sons
not to dress, eat, nor drink in the same manner as the sons of the former wife.
Their rising dwelling place, entering, and leaving were far removed from each other
but still the sons of the former wife did not love.
Then the middle [third] son of the former wife broke the command of the King of Wei and was condemned to die.
the Indulgent Mother was so sad and depressed
that the cincture encircling her lessened a foot.
Morning and night she labored diligently in order to redeem his fault.
Some men spoke to the Indulgent Mother, saying,
"Since men who do not love their mother are the worst,
why labor diligently, be sorrowful, and fearful like this?"
The indulgent Mother said,
"If they were my own sons,
although they did not love me,
yet I would save them from misfortune and rid them of harm.
If it is only for my stepsons that I do not do this,
what difference is there between me and other mothers?
Their father had them as orphans
and he ordered me to be their stepmother.
A stepmother should be like a [real] mother.
If she is to be a human mother and cannot love her sons,
can she be said to be kind?
To love one's relatives and to be selfish toward one's adopted relatives,
can that be called righteousness?"
If one is unkind and unrighteous also,
how can one be established in this world?
And although one does not love me,
how can I forget righteousness?"
Thereafter she diputed the case.
When King Anli of Wei heard of it,
he exalterd her righteousness and said,
"Since the Indulgent Mother is such a person,
how can I but pardon her son?
Then he pardoned her son- 25 -
and restored him to his family.
From that time on, the five sons lovingly attached themselves to the Indulgent Mother
and were as afable as if they made up one family.
The Indulgent Mother used gradual steps of propriety and righteousness
to lead her eight sons.
All became high officials for the minister of Wei.
and each one perfected himself in propriety and righteousness.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Indulgent Mother had singleness of purpose.
The Book of Songs says:
"The cuckoo is on the mulberry-tree; //
Her young go astray; //
But good people, gentle folk- //
Their ways are righteous. //
Their ways are righteous, //
Their thoughts are constrained. //
It speaks of her singleness of heart,
for the cuckoo shows the same affection in nourishing all her seven offspring
and the Superior Man uses the same righteous principle in developing all things.
A heart with singleness of purpose can serve a hundred masters;
a heart with a hundred intentions cannot serve one master.
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The wife of Mang Mao
was stepmother to five sons.
She was loving, gracious, humane, and righteous;
she helped and cared for her adopted sons.
Although they did not love her,
she was as careful of them as if they were her own.
A stepmother such as this
can truly be honored.
THE MOTHER OF TIAN JI
She was the mother of Tian Jizi of Qi.
Tian Jizi who was minister of Qi,
received from the lower officers interest on loans, a hundred "i,"
which he presented as a gift to his mother.
The mother said,
"Since you were minister for only three years,
your salary was never so much as this.
Is this the money for the care of the officials?
How have you obtained this?"
He replied,
"Truly, I received it from the subordinate officers."
His mother said,
"I have learned that an official acts ethically, is chaste in conduct,
and does not act for unfair gain.
He manifests all thruth
and does not act falsety.
If an affair is not righteous,
he does not think on it in his heart;
if profit is unjust,
it does not enter his house.
His words match his actions
and his emotions are in accord with his appearance.
At present, the ruler has established an office in order to treat you well
and a good salary to reward you.
By your words and actions then, you can repay your prince.
Now the minister should serve his prince- 26 -
as the son serves his father.
He exerts to the utmost his strength and ability;
his faithfulness is without deceit;
and his duty is fulfilled loyalty.
If duty requires death, he obeys the command.
Since he is incorrupt and just,
he accomplishes his work without misfortune.
Today, on the contrary,
you appear to be far removed from loyalty.
One, who as aminister is disloyal,
as a son is disobedient also.
I will not possess
wealth that is unjust;
I will not have a son
who is not filial.
You may rise."
Tian Jizi, being ashamed, went out his money. ??? correct this
and returned
He, himself, sent to King Xuan
and then asked to be punished.
When King Zuan heard of this,
he was greatly with the righteousness of the mother.
Afterwards, he pardoned the crime of Jizi,
gave back his position as minister,
and rewarded the mother with public money.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
The mother of Ji was incorrupt and transformed others.
The Book of Songs says:
"No, indeed, that lord, //
Does not sup the sup of idleness." //
If he were without merit, he would not
consider consuming the royal grant.
How much less would [he consider] receiving money!
The Sung says:
The mother of Ji
was incorrupt, pure, just and upright.
She reprimanded her son for receiving money
and considered it as unvirtuous.
In the service of loyalty and filial piety,
a man should expend his talent and exhaust his strenght.
The Superior Man receives emoluments

div.head: 2 賢明傳 BIGRAPHIES OF THE VIRTOUS AND WISE

p.seg: QUEEN JIANG OF [KING] XUAN OF THE ZHOU.
Queen Jiang of [King] Xuan of the Zhou [Dynasty]
was the daughter of the Marquis of Qi;
she was both talented and possessed virtue.
If the matter was not proper, she would not speak;
if the act was not according to the rites, she would not move.
King Xuan usually went to bed early and rose late
and the Queen wife did not go out of her room.
When Queen Jiang [came out of her room], she took the hairpins from her hair and the earrings from her ears
and awaited punishment on the palace tribunal.
She ordered her governess to get word in to the King saying,
"The stupidity
and licentious heart of your wife have manifested themselves.
It has come to such a pass that she causes the King to fail in propriety and to come late to court
so that it is seen that the King enjoys the beauty of women and has forgotten virtue.
Now if he takes pleasure in the beauty of women,
he must love extravagance and the satisfaction of his desires
which bring the flourishing of disorder.
The source of rise of disorder
comes from me
and I dare to acknowledge my fault."
The King said,
"I, the King, am without virtue;
in fact, I myself have given birht to these faults.
It is not the crime of my wife."
Thereupon he reinstated Queen Jiang and was diligent about the business of governing.
He was early at court, retired from it at a late hour,
and in the end he brought about a revival of the fame of the [dynasty].
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
Queen Jiang was excellent in respectful criticism and was virtous in conduct.
This was her etiquette:
When whe waited on her Lord,- 30 -
she used a candle to enter [the building].
When she reached her Lord's quarters,
having put out the candle,
she advanced to the middle of the room
where she removed her court clothes
and dressed in her negligee.
After that she entered to serve her Lord.
When the cock crew
and the Music Master struck the drum to announce the dawn,
the Queen Wife made a sound with the [ivory] ornaments on her girdle and departed.
The Book of Songs says:
"Grave in deportment, //
Of reputation consistent." //
It also says:
"The mulberry on the lowland, // how graceful, //
Its leaves, how fresh! //
Now I have seen my lord, //
His high fame holds fast. //
Now the wife uses her beauty for love
and her virtue for strengh.
The virtous conduct of Lady Jiang can be said to hold fast.
The Song says:
This excellent Queen Jiang
whose virtue leads to a virtuous life!
Whatever was befitting, she took action to perform it.
She was properly married to [King] Xuan of Zhou
and modestly pointed out his faults.
King Xuan understood well.
Early and late he followed the right way
of governing and became a rejuvenated ruler.
JI OF WEI, WIFE OF DUKE HUAN OF QI
Ji of Wei
was the daughter of the Marquis of Wei
and the wife of Duke Huan of Qi.
Duke Huan liked licentious music
and Ji of Wei on this account would not listen to the notes of Zhang and Wei
Duke Huan was using Guan Zhong and Ning Qi
to form a hegemony [of the states].
The nobles were all at his court
but only the duke of Wei did not come.
Duke Huan planned with Guan Zhong to attack Wei,
then closed the court and entered the apartments.
Ji of Wei, having watched Duke Huan [from the distance],
took out her hairpins and earrings
and loosened her ornamental girdle.
She came down the hall and bowed twice before him
saying,
"I desire to beg forgiveness for the offence of Wey."
The Duke then said,
"I have no quarrel with Wei;
how is it that [you], Ji, ask for pardon for an offense?"
She replied, saying,
"I have learned this:
Rulers have three moods.
How evident is that of joy and pleasure! It concerns the person, the form, and lewd music.
It is the mood of the bell and drum and of wine and the banquet. - 31 -
How quiet the mood of purity and peace! It concerns thought and spirit, repose and self-repression.
It is the mood of mourning and misfortune.
How angry that of satisfaction and pride! It concerns the haughty movement of the hand and foot.
It is the mood of of attack and punishment.
Today, I looked at my Lord raising his footsteps high,
his aspect severe, and his voice raised;
his intent was to attack Wei.
This is the reason that I asked pardon."
Duke Huan gave his promise [not to attack Wei].
On the following day, when the court was held,
Guan Zhong rushed in, saying,"
"This morning your Majesty arrived at the court with a respectful air,
your anger suppressed,
and your words sedate.
there is no intention to punish any country.
this is to pardon Wei."
Duke Huan said,
"Very good!"
Then he established Ji of Wei as his legal wife
and he gave to Guan Zhong the honoray title of "Zhong Fu"
He said,
"Let the wife rule the inner apartments
and Guan Zhong manage outer affairs.
I, [the King], although unwise,
am still capable of establishing my place in the world."
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Ji of Wei was loyal and had good conduct.
The Book of Songs says:
"Truly such a lady //
Is a beauty matchless in the land."
The Song says:
Ji of Wey of [Duke] Huan of Qi
was loyal and sincere
[but] the King loved lewd music.
Ji was acting correctly
but she beheld his appearance and asked for pardon for a fault.
Duke Huan admired her,
ordered her to rule the inner apartments,
and established her as his legal consort.
JIANG OF QI, WIFE OF DUKE WEN OF JIN
Jiang of Qi
was a lineal female descendant of Duke Huan of Qi
and the wife of Duke Wen of Jin.
In beginning Duke Wen's father, Duke Xian,
took a concubine from the country of Li,
who slandered and killed the crown prince, Shen Sheng.
Duke Wen, known as Chong Er, the duke's son,
fled together with his uncle, Fan, to the barbarians
and then came to Qi.
Duke Huan presented him with a lineal female descendant as his wife
He received him very well
by presenting him with twenty teams of horses.
He wished to die in Qi
and said:
"Man's life is for peace and happiness, and that is all.
Who knows anything else?"
Zifan (his uncle), knew that duke Wen wished to settle permanently in Qi
but he (Zifan) wished to go and he worried over it.
While he was plotting with his followers under a mulberry tree,
the servant who attended the silkworms was present too.
This servant told lady Qiang.
Qiang killed her
and spoke to the duke's son, saying:
"Your followers are preparing for you to go away.
I have already done away with the one who heard of it.
(You,) the duke's son, must comply with them.
It is not permitted to doubt (success),
for if you doubt, you cannot accomplish your destiny.
From the time that you left Jin
Jin has not had a peaceful year,
and yet Heaven has not ruined Jin.
If the one who is to possess the country of Jin
is not you, who is it?
If you make an effort for it
Shangdi will bless you
but if you doubt, you will certainly have misfortune."
The Duke's son said:
"I will not move.
I must die here!
Jiang said,
"You cannot do that.
The poem of Zhou says:
"'In a great host go the travellers, //
Each bent on keeping his place.' //
Morning and night they press along the road
and still fear that they will not arrive.
How much more the one who desires to cherish this ease!
How will he arrive?
If a man does not seek his place,
how can he attain it?
The disorder [in your home country] has not a long existence,
and the Duke's son must possess Jin."
The Duke's son would not listen,
so Jiang and the uncle, Fan, planned
to get him drunk
and to carry him away in order to go to Chin.
When he awoke from his drunken stupor,
the Duke's son, using a spear, chased his uncle, Fan, saying:
"If this business is successful then it is all right;
if it is not successful,
then I shall eat your flesh.
Shall I not eat to repleation?"
Thereafter he went on
and they passed through Cao, Song, Zheng, and Chu, and entered Qin.
Duke Mu of Qin then used his troops to bring the Duke's son back to Jin.
The people of Jin killed Duke Huai and set up the Duke's son, Chong Er, as Ruler.
He became Duke Wen
ad he welcomes Jiang of Qi as his wife.
Thereafter he controlled the empire
and was the noble's sworn lord.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Jiang of Qi was pure and would not defile herself.
He was able to train the Superior Man in goodness.
The Book of Songs says:
"That beautiful Shu Ji
Is good at capping stories."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Jiang of Qi was just and honest.
Her words and actions were not careless.
She urged Wen of Jin to action
and also to return to his kingdom without doubting.
The Duke's son would not listen.
Jiang plotted with Fan
to get him drunk and carry him off.
In the end he became the feudal lord of the whole country.
JI of Duke Mu of Chin
Ji of Duke Mu of Qin
Ji of Mu was the wife of Duke Mu of Qin
and the daughter of Duke Xian of Jin.
She was the elder sister of the Crown Prince, Shen Sheng,
from the same mother but from a different mother than Duke Hui,
and was both talented and correct in deportment.
When Duke Xian had killed the Crown Prince, Shen Sheng,
he drove out all the Duke's sons,
and Duke Hui, who was called Yi Wu, the Duke's son,
fled to [the country of] Liang.
When Duke Xian died,
since he had the aid of Qin,
he [Hui] established himself in power.
When he first succeeded to the throne, Ji of Mu ordered him to take in all the Duke's sons, saying:
"The Duke's clan
is the foundation of the ruler."
Duke Hui did not use them
and he also failed to keep up the presents to Qin
Jin experiencing a famine
asked grain from Qin
and Qin gave it to them.
When Qin experienced famine,
they asked grain from JIn
but Jin did not give it to them.
Thereupon, Qin raised troops to engage in battle with Jin.
They took the Ruler of Jin prisoner and returned.
Duke Mu of Qin said,
"Clean up the temple of the ancestors.
I, [the King], shall bring the King of Jin there to interview him."
Ji of Mu heard this
and together with the Heir Apparent, Ying, the Duke's son Xiong,
and [her daughters] Jian and Pi,
all wore the clothes and badges of mourning and they walked on brambles in order to meet him.
Moreover, she sent in a petition to Duke Mu, saying
" The Heavens overhead send down calamity
and it causes two Princes not to greet each other with presents of precious stones and silk
but to begin hostilities.
I and the wives
cannot teach each other
and we disgrace our Prince's life.
The morning that the Prince of Jin enters in,
that evening I die.
Only you, my lord, determine it."
Since the Duke was afraid,
then he [stopped and] sheltered them all at Ling Tai.
The Great Officers begged leave to bring the Duke of Jin into the city
The Duke said,
"Having taken the Duke of Jin prisoner, I was returning with great spoils.
Today may bring death.
How can I do so? "
And so he changed his mind and sheltered the Duke of Jin.
He gave him seven oxen as a gift and sent him home.
Ji of Mu died
and then her younger brother, Zhong Er, entered Qin
which country presented him with Jin
This one was Duke Wen of Jin.
The Heir Apparent, Ying, thought of the favor of his mother
and accompanied his uncle's family.- 34 -
He composed a poem saying,
I shall accompany my uncle's family
and say upon arriving at Wei Yang,
'What can I present him with?
A royal cart with excellent steeds!'"
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
The Indulgent Mother bave birth to a filial son.
The Book of Songs says:
" [He] scrupulously attentive to decorum, //
Will become a pattern to his people." //
This could be said of Ji of Mu.
The Song says:
The wife of Mu of Qin
was the older sister of Hui of Jin.
Qin seized the Lord of Jin
and the wife's tears flowed
for she was heartbroken that she could not rescue him.
When she was about to die,
Duke Mu treated her justly
and afterwards freed her younger brother.
Ji, Nee Fan of King Zhuang of Chu
Ji,
nee Fan, was the wife of King Zhuang fo Chu.
When Zhuang ascended the throne,
he liked to hunt wild animals.
Fan Ji admonished him [about this] but he did not stop,
[so] then she would not eat the flesh of birds and animals.
The king reformed his ways
and was diligent in govenmental affairs.
The King usually listened at court and left off late.
Ji descended to the palace to meet him and said,
"How is it that you stopped so late?
Have you become tireless?
The King said,
"When I converse with talented men,
I do not know weariness."
Ji said,
"The King speaks of talented men. Who, I pray"
[The King] said,
"Yu Qiu Zi."
Ji coverered her mouth and laughed.
The King said,
"How is it that Ji is laughing?"
She said,
"Yu Qiu Zi is capable but only capable;
he is not yet loyal."
The King said,
"Why do you say that?"
She replied, saying,
I [your wife] have looked after dusting and hairdressing for eleven years
and have sent out men to Zheng and Wei
to search for Mei Ren to send in before the King.
Today, the concubines more capable than I are two;
and those of the same class as I are seven.
And yet, how can I but desire to monopolize the favors of the King?
I have learned that
in the hall there should be many women
and thereby [the King ] may tell of their ability.
I cannot let my privae [desires] obstruct the public [good]
and I desire the King to see more and understand men's ability.
Now, Yu Qiu Zi has been minister of Chu for more than ten years
but those whom he has introduced [for office] were either his sons, younger brothers,
or men of his tribe.
I have not heard that he advanced the capable or retired the unfit.
This cuts off the superior man and obstructs the road [of advancement] for the superior man
and obstructs the road [of advancement] for the talented ones.
is diloyalty;
not to know ability,
that is ignorance.
Was it not all right
that I should laugh at this?
The King was pleased [with her answer].
The next day,
the King, using Ji's words, made the matter known to Yu Qiuzi.
Qiuzi, not knowing what to reply, left his seat.
On this account when he had gone to his home,
he ordered messengers to meet Sun Shu'ao and recommend him.
The King used him as Overseer of the Officials
and he ruled Chu for three years
but King Zhuang became head of the feudal princes.
The Annals of Chu say:
"The feudal reign of King Zhuang
was by the strnegth of Fan Ji."
The Book of Songs says:
"Oh, you Great Officers, reiture early,
Do not fatigue our lord".
It also says
"Meek and reverent both day and night,
In humble awe discharging their tasks."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Fan Ji was humble, yielding
and had no envy.
sh presented and advanced Mei Ren
to dwell with her in the same place.
By such means she criticized Qiuzi's
obstructing the road for worthy men.
Zhuang of Chu used her words,
and by her merit and skill afterwards became the feudal lord.
The Woman of Zhounan
The Woman of Zhounan
was the wife of an official of Zhounan.
The official received an order
to regulate the floods.
When the time for his return passed and he did not come back,
the wife feared that he had been remiss in the service of his king.
Therefore she recounted with her neighbors the conversations which she was accustomed to have with the official,
[namely], the fact that the nation was in great distress,
should urge him on;
he should have no cause for anger
but should avoid giving sorrow to his father and mother.
Formerly Shun plowed on the hill of Li,
fished in the Lei Marsh,
and scoured his rice at the river's edge.
This was not [the proper] work of Shun,
but he did it- 36 -
in order to nourish his father and mother.
His home was poor and his parents old
but he served the public good without choosing an official position.
He, himself, carried water and pounded in a mortar.
He did not choose a wife and marry her.
Therefore, while his mother and father were living,
[he thought] he ought to live in the same manner as when he was young.
He was lacking in no duty and was most righteous.
He did not encounter misfortune or injury and all that.
Now the Feng and the Huang are not found in small nets;
nor does the Qilin enter the pitfall; and the dragon of the thickets and morasses does not come into the dried up marsh.
O the wisdom of the birds and animals!
Even they know to flee from injury
but how much more should men know to do so
If he is born into a disordered world
and cannot maintain reasonable principles
or he is driven by a tyrant
and cannot act righteously,
still he will hold office
because his father and mother are living.
Then she spoke a poem saying:
"The beam has a red tail; //
The royal house is ablaze //
But though it is ablaze, //
My father and mother are very dear." //
By such means the Man of Noble sentiments knows that the Woman of Zhounan could correct her husband.
The Song says:
The wife of the official of Zhou!
Her husband went out to regulate the floods.
Whereas she warned him not to be idle
but to exert himself for his father and mother,
since all perform their service
to keep harm at a distance on behalf of their living parents.
She spoke the poem of the Fang Yu, [Bream],
in order to warn her husband.
Nyu Zong of Pao of Song
Nyu Zong
was the wife of Pao Su of Song
and took care of her mother-in-law very diligently.
Pao Su filled a position in Wei for three years
and there took a mistress.
Nyu Zong waited on her mother-in-law with great attentiveness.
She, having in quired about her husband from many travellers,
learned that he gave many presents to his secret mistress.
Nyu Song's sister-in-law spoke [to her], saying,
"You can leave now."
Nyu Song said,
"On what groounds [can I leave]?"
The sister-in-law said,
"When a husband has what he likes,
then why should you stay?"
Nyu Xong said,
"A woman once having drunk of the marriage cup does not change,
and if her husband dies, she does not marry [again].
She takes in hand the hempen fibres,
oversees the silken cocoons,
weaves silken clothes, bands and cords
in order to provide clothing
and in order to serve her husband's family.
She clarifies wine for libations
and presents viands and food in order to serve her parents-in-law.
She conciders devoteness to one man as chastity
and docile compliance as obedience.
How is it that love of a single husband's family is not considered good?
If she had licentiousness in her heart,
but clings to a fondness for her husband's family,
I do not understand such goodness.
According to the [Book] of Li,
the Emperor may have twelve women,
the Nobles nine,
the Ministers three,
and the Army Officials two.
At present my husband is an army official
and so if he has two [women],
is not that fitting?
Moreover, the woman has seven reasons for being divorced [by her husband]
but there is not one righteous reason for her to leave him.
Of the seven reasons for divorce
the foremost is to envy the first wife;
base lust, stealing,
shrewishness, contemptuous pride,
childnessness, and to have a repulsive disease
are all next in importance.
My sister-in-law, if you teach me the propriety of living in the [husband's] home- 38 -
and on the other hand desire me to act as one who had been rejected,
how can I use your advice?"
Thereafter, she would not listen
and served her mother-in-law more diligently.
The Duke of Song heard of it
and glorified her village.
She was given the honorary title, Nyu Zong.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Nyu Zong was humble and understood propriety.
The Book of Songs says:
"Good is his every attitude and air, //
So cautious, so composed! //
Following none but ancient teachings, //
Striving only for dignity and good deportment. //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Nyu Zong of Pao of Song
was fond of propriety and understood principles.
The husband had a secret mistress,
but she did not change on this account.
She, [Nyu Zong] was satisfied to carry on the wife's role.
She did not listen to her sister-in-law.
The Duke of Song extolled her virtue
and honored her village.
The Wife of Zhao Shuai of Jin
The wife of Zhao Shuai of Jin
was the daughter of Duke Wen of Jin,
and she was called Ji of Zhao.
In the beginning, when Duke Wen was [only] a Duke's son,
he fled together with Zhao Shuai to the Di Tribe.
The people of Di presented two women, Shu Wei and Ji Wei for the Duke's son.
The Duke gave Shu Wei as wife to Zhao Shuai
and she gave birth to Dun, [a son].
When they returned to their own country,
Duke Wen gave his own daughter, Zhao Ji, as a wife to Zhao Shuai.
She gave birth to Yuan Tong, Ping Gua, and Lou Ying.
Zhao Ji begged [her husband] to welcome Dun with his mother and to receive them [into the home].
Zhao Shuai excused himself and did not dare to [do it].
Zhao Ji said,
"You cannot act thus.
The husband obtains what is pleasant and he neglects the old [wife];
this is to neglect righteousness.
To like the new and despise the old,
is ingratitude.
In time of difficulties, you hold on to someone to struggle along with,
and in time of wealth and honor, you disregard that one,
that is to be lacking in propriety.
My lord has cast aside these three.
How can you command men?
Even I feel no reason to serve as your wife.
Does not the poem say:
" ' He who plucks greens, plucks cabbage //
Does not judge by the lower parts. //
In my reputation there is no flaw, //
I am yours till death.' //
She shares with [her husband] coldness and suffering,
and although she has some faults,
how is it that he will not go even to death with her?
How can you be at peace with the new and forget the old?
It [the poem] also says:
" ' You feast your new relations //
And think me no fit company.' //
And thus you injure her.
My lord, then go to meet her.
Do not enjoy the new one and reject the old one."
Zhao Shuai gave his promise
and as Shu Wei and Dun were coming, he went to meet them.
Since Ji considered Dun as talented,
she asked that he be established as legal heir
and placed her three sons below him;
she considered Shu Wei as the legal wife
and placed herself below her.
When Dun was president of the lower Court,
he thought of Zhao Ji's yielding the favor [to him]
and he asked that Ji's middle son, Ping Gua, be the Ruler of the clan.
He said,
"He
is the beloved son of the ruler's wife Ji.
If she were not the ruler's wife,
then I, myself, would sill be a Di, [a barbarian]
and how could I have become a minister?"
Duke Cheng permitted it [to be done].
Ping Gua, thereafter was held as Ruler of the Duke' clan.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Zhao Ji was honored but gave up her right.
The Book of Songs says:
"Reverence and goodness so mild
Are the foundations of inner power."
The Song says:
The Lady Zhao Shuai regulated her deportment
and distinguished [matters] clearly.
Although of high and noble birth,
she was not jealous of a concubine.
She personaly served Shu Wei
whose son, Dun, was made the heir.
The Su[perior Man praised her.
Her deportment was excellent and perfect.
The Wife of Dazi of Tao
She was the wife of Dazi, an official of Tao.
Dazi had spent three years in subjugating Tao
and his reputation was not very glorious
but his family fortune had increased three times.
Although his wife acmonished him frequently, he did not accept her advice.
He filled office for five years
and a hundred carts followed him when he returned home on leave.
His tribesmen slew a cow [for feast] and congratulated him
but his wife remained alone holding her child and weeping silently.
The mother-in-law in anger said,
"Why this unpropitious omen?"
The wife replied,
" My husband's ability is small and his position great;
this is called 'stirring up trouble.'- 40 -
He is without merit and his family affluent.
This is called 'piling up misfortune'.
Formerly in Chu, the Chief Minister, Ziwen Zhi ruled the country.
His family was poor and the country wealthy;
the ruler was sedate and the people respectful;
and hence there was prosperity and happiness for his posterity.
His name was hanced down to later generations.
Today, my husband's [situation is] the contrary, be
for his family is wealthy and his duty is great
but he does not regard the later misfortune [that will follow].
I, the wife, learned that the South Mountain had a black leopard.
There was fog and rain for seven days and he did not come down the mountain to eat.
Why was that?
He wished to make his hair glossy and he became spotted.
For this reason he hid and avoided misfortune.
If the dog and the pig do not choose their food in order to fatten their bodies
but sit [in one place] they must die.
At present, my husband is ruling Tao.
His family is wealthy and the kingdom is poor;
the ruler is not sedate
and the people are not respectful.
It is evident proof of the ruin to come.
I desire to escape with my little son."
The mother- in- law was angry
and therefore cast her out.
After a period of years,
the family of Dazi was really considered a robber family, to be punished capitally.
Only the mother was spared because she was old.
The wife then returned with her little son and cared for the mother-in-law.
In the end she died a natural death.
The Man of Noble Sentiments' says: Dazi's wife was able to exchange righteousness for profit.
Although she violated propriety by asking to leave [her husband],
in the end she used her entire strenght to restore propriety.
This may be called farsighted wisdom.
The Book of Songs says:
"All your many plans //
Are not equal to what I propose." //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Dazi ruled Tao
and his family wealth increased three times.
His wife admonished him but he would not listen.
He knew his fault but did not correct it.
The wife wept alone and her mother was angry.
She, [the wife], was sent to her mother's home.- 41 -
When Dazi met calalmity,
the wife returned to care for her mother-in-law.
The Wife of Liu Xia Hui
She was the wife of Liu Xia Hui, minister of Lu.
While Liu Xia Hui was living in the country of Lu,
he was thrice dismissed from office but did not leave
because he pitied the people and would save them from anarchy.
His wife said,
"Are you not disgraced?
The Superior Man has two reasons for disgrace:
if the country is without good government and he is honored [by office],
it is a disgrace;
if the country is well governed and he is not honored [by office],
it is a disgrace.
At present, in this disordered generation,
you have been dismissed three times from office and do not go.
This also approaches disgrace."
Liu Xia Hui said,
"The kind and docile people
are about to sink into ruin;
what am I able to do?
Those men are those men,
I am myself.
Although those men are naked,
how can they defile me?"
He held a lower position.
When Liu Xia died,
his disciples were about to write his eulogy
and his wife said,
"Are you going to write a eulogy of my husband's virtue?
The knowledge of several disciples [of his] is not equal to that of his wife's."
Then she wrote a eulogy saying,
"My husband was one who did not boast!
My husband was one who did not visit high officials!
My husband was sincere and honest: he dealt with men without injuring them.
He adapted himself to the weak and followed the common people
but was not defiled.
He exposed himself to disgrace to serve the common people
and his virtue was still greater
for although he met dismissal three times,
to the end, it [his virtue], could not be hidden from view.
This kind and urbane official
was always able to stand trials.
Alas, how sad!
then he departed this world.
Probably those advanced in years
will follow!
Alas, how pitiful!
the soul and spirit have escaped.
