My husband's title after death
is fittingly called 'Hui' [Gracious]."
His disciples agreed with her that this be his eulogy
and they were unable to correct even one character.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Liu Xia Hui's wife was able to glorify her husband.
The Book of Songs says:
"They know one thing, //- 42 -
But they know that one thing."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The wife of Liu Xia Hui
was virtous, intelligent, and had literary ability.
When Liu Xia died,
his disciples were certainly present
and when they were about to write a eulogy for Xia Hui
his wife chose "Hui" as his honorary title [at death]
and related in order his actions.
They were unable to change it.
The Wife of Qian Lou of Lu
She was the wife of the Teacher, Qian Lou [of the kingdom
The teacher died
and Cengzi and his disciples went to mourn for him.
His wife [the Teacher's] came out of the door [to meet them]
and Cengzi condoled with her.
He entered the hall
and saw the Teacher's corpse which was below the [North] window
with a pillow of unburnt bricks and a mat of rice straw.
[He wore] a wadded robe without an upper garment
and was covered with a cotton quilt
but his hands and feet were not entirely enshrouded.
If you covered the head, then the feet were seen;
if you covered the feet, then the head appeared.
Cengzi said,
"Place the coverlet obliquely,
then it will enshroud him."
The wife said,
"If you place it obliquely, there will be some part left over.
It is not as good as being placed on straight and still not being sufficient [to cover him].
The Teacher's reason for it not being placed obliquely
can be adduced here:
When he was living he did not like crooked things,
and when he is dead to cover him crookedly
would not be [in accord] with the Teacher's intention.
Ceng Zi was unable to answer [this argument] and thereafter wept for him saying,
"Alas!
This is the end of the Teacher.
What will be his epitaphal name?"
His wife said,
"Use 'Kang' [Joy] as the honorary name."
Cengzi said,
"While the Teacher was living,
he ate but did not satisfy hunger;
he clothed himself but did not cover his body entirely.- 43 -
he died but his hands and feet were not enshrouded
and by his side were offerings of neither wine nor meat.
While living, he did not attain his happiness,
and when dead he did not attain his glory.
What happiness was there for him that his honorary name should be called 'Kang' [Joy]?"
The wife said,
"In former times, when the Prince wished to confer some office of government on him [the Teacher]
and use him as a prime minister
he refused and did not accept the position.
This was an excessive honor.
The Prince once honored him with thirty zhong of grain
but the Teacher excused himself and did not accept it.
This was excessive wealth.
That Teacher
was contented with tasteless, insipid things of this world
and was peaceful in the humble position of the nation.
He was not sad in poverty and a humble position;
he was not elated over wealth and honor.
He sought benevolence and attained it;
he sought righteousness and achieved it.
His honorary title is 'Kang' [Joy].
Is it not befitting?"
Zengzi said,
"Aye! Such a man and he had such a wife."
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Wife of Qian Lou was happy in poverty and acted according to reason.
The Book of Songs says:
"That beautiful Shu Ji //
Is good at capping stories." //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
When Qian Lou died,
his wife alone directed the funeral
and Cengzi came to the funeral.
Qian Lou was clohed in a gray, cotton robe;
he was peaceful in a lowly position, and was contented with insipid food.
He did not seek wealth and prosperous maintenance.
His corpse was not concealed by the shroud
yet his honorary name was called "Kang" [Joy].
The Wife of The Charioter of the Minister og Qi
She was the wife of the charioter of Yanzi,the minister of Qi.
and her honorary title was "Ming Fu."
Yan was about to set out
and Ming Fu furtively watched her husband acting as the Minister's charioter.
Screened by high canopy,
he whipped up his four horses
an his manner was grandiose
and self-satisfied.
When he returned,
his wife asked to leave him, saying,
"Your vileness and baseness just suits you!"
The husband said,
"How is that?"
The wife said,
"Yanzi is not fully five feet tall,
yet he acts as the Minister of Qi,
and his name is illustrious among all the nobles.
Today, from the gateway, I observed his courage
and his respect for those below him.
His thoughtfulness was very deep.
Now, your body is eight feet tall
and so on account of it you are the charioteer
but your manner was grandiose as if you were very self-satisfied.
I,[your wife], therefore ask to leave you."
Her husband thanked her, saying,
"Please allow me to correct myself. How would that be?
The wife said,
"Embrace the wisdom of Yanzi
and add to it your eight feet of height.
Then your person will be benign and righteous,
Serve your enlightened lord,
and your name must be rendered famous.
Moreover, I have heard, 'Prefer glory in righteousness, and a low position
to empty pride in order to be honored.
On this account, her husband having severely reproached himself,
studied the way of humility
and advanced as if he were never satisfied.
Yanzi wondered at [this change] and asked him the cause of it.
He presented the true explanation
and thereupon Yanzi praised his ability to attain virtue and to correct himself.
He raised him to the [rank of] Jing Gong,
used him as an official,
and made his wife illustrious as "Ming Fu".
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Ming Fu knew excellence
and hence she praised men who were able to attain it.

but her intention was still the same and pure.
the mother urged her to leave and return home
but she wrote the ["plantago"] poem and did not listen to her.
Later generations praised her
for they judged her to be observing chastity.
THE WIFE OF DUKE ZHUANG OF LI
The wife of Zhuang of Li
was the daughter of the Marquis of Wei
an the wife of Duke Zhuang of Li.
When she went [to her husband], since they had unlike desires
and different interests,
she had not had the chance of seeing him
and was far from satisfied.
Although the governess pitied the wife's virtue,
the Duke, on the other hand, did not receive
her nor take pity on her lost cause.
[The nurse] also feared that he had appeared to let her go
but had not yet set a time on her going
and so she spoke to the wife saying,
the principle of the husband and wife
is that there is righteousness and then they are united.
If there is not righteousness,then they are seperated.
Now, you have not obtained satisfaction;
why do you not leave him?"
And then she [the governess] spoke a poem, saying:
"How few of us are left, how few! //
Why do we not go back? " //
The wife said,
"The principle of husband and wife
is unity and that is all.
Although that one [my husband] has not treated me as his wife,
how can I depart from the duty of the wife? "
Then she spoke a poem saying:
"Were it not for our prince and his concerns, //
What should we be doing here in the dew? " //- 78 -
To the end she maintained chastity and devotion to one husband;
nor did she reliquish the way of the wife,
for she waited on her husband's command.
The Man of Noble Sentiments related this in a poem.- 78 -
The Song says:
The wife of Zhuang of Li
maintained her deportment without relaxing
but Duke Zhuang would not meet with her.
Although her actions were chaste,
her governess urged her to leave
and spoke to her the poem, "Shi Wei," [How few of us are left]
The wife remained faithful to one [husband]
and to the end she was unwilling to return hime.
Meng Ji
was the eldest daughter of the Hua family
and the wife of Duke xiao of Qi.
She esteemed propriety, chastity and singleness of purpose.
She passed the usual age without marrying.
Someone [from the country] of Qi asked her in marriage,
but he did not prepare the ceremonies completely
an in the end she would not go [to his home].
She would not step on the mat of a man
nor speak to a stranger;
she held aloof from and avoided the appearance of evil.
The man of Qi was not able to fulfill the ceremoneies in asking her in marriage,
and the country of Qi remarked on her chastity and filial devotion.
When Duke Xiao heard of it,
he studied the proprieties and went in person for the bride to the home of the Hua family.
Her father and mother accompanied Meng Ji but not out of the hall.
In the ancestral hall
the mother tied her ornamental bridal cincture
and admonished her sayhing,
"You must be respectful! You must be cautious!
Morning ans evening do not neglect the palace affairs."
At the top of the east stairs, her father admonished her saying,
"Rise early and go late to bed.
Do not be disobededient
and unless there is some serious impediment to obeying the king's commands,
obey them!
On the steps [to the gate], the mothers warned her
saying,
"Be sade! Be sedate!
You must fulfill your father and mother's command to the last.
From morning to night do not become lazy.
the lapel and the embroidered cincture
bespeak your father and mother's words."
Just inside the gate, her aunts and sisters warned her
saying
"Both early and late be without fault.
Your lapel and broad sash
keep you from forgetting the words of your father and mother."
Duke Xiao personally met Meng Ji with her father and mother
and she regarded her parents three times and went out.
[The Duke] himself took the reins,- 79 -
personally drove the cart for three turns of the wheel,
and then turned to look at Meng Ji in the cart.
Thereafter he received her into the palace.
After three month, there was the bride's worship of the ancestors of the husband
and subsequently they proceeded with the duties of husband and wife.
After they had lived together for a long time,
the Duke was on a pleasure trip to Lang Xie
and Meg Ji nee Hua was accompanying him.
The cart ran away,
Ji fell out, and the cart broke up.
Duke Xiao sent a four horse chariot to bring Ji back home
but Ji ordered the assistant charioteer to open out the curtain [of the cart] to screen her off
and she sent the governess to answer the messenger, saying
"I have learned that when the royal wife passes over the threshold [of the gate],
she must ride in a cart with seats and with curtains on four sides.
If she leaves the hall
she must obey the governess and matron;
on entering or leaving [the room]
she sounds her stone bracelets and cincture pendents.
When she has put on her personal ornaments, then she ties up her entwining silks;
while in the wilderness, whe takes a curtain of the cart to screen off herself
thus keeping her heart upright and her purpose single.
She also regulates her own desires.
as for the chariot without seats and without curtains,
I dare not receive a command to ride in it,
nor in the wilderness
do I dare remain long without protection.
This is the third time he has neglected many of the rules of propriety;
it is better to die an early death
than to live without the rules of propriety."
The messenger went quickly to tell the Duke
and to take a cart with seats.
Before the messenger's return,
she tried to commit suicide.
the governess tried without ceasing to revive her
and said to her,
"The messenger has come.
The curtained cart is prepared."
Madame Ji revived
and thereafter she mounted the cart and returned home.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Meng Ji was fond of propriety.
Propriety [is as follows]:
If a woman goes out, she must go in a curtained carriage
and her clothes entwined in silk.
When she is married,
she returns home, and asks about her sisters
but not her brothers,
thus avoiding suspicion.
The Book of Songs says:
"That lady his daughter, //
Thick and lovely hair." //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Meng Ji loved propriety
and maintained the regulations of chastity very devotedly.
She avoided all suspicion of evil
and to the end she did not display her beauty.- 80 -
In travelling she would not ride standing up
and whatever was improper she would not do.
The Superior Man eulogized her.
From ancient times, widows were like her.
THE WIFE OF THE RULER OF XI
This wife
was the wife of the ruler of Xi.
Chu having invaded Xi,
defeated her badly
took prisoner her ruler,
and ordered him to guard the gate.
He [i,e,, the ruler of Chu] took as wife the wife [of the ruler of Xi]
and received her into his harem.
When the King of Chu went for a pleasure trip,
the wife went to see the ruler of Xi
and spoke to him saying,
"Man must die once and it is over.
Why come to self-inflicted bitterness?
I, the wife, will not forget my former lord for a moment
and to the end I shall not give my person in a second betrothal.
If living on this earth we are separated,
why not die and return under the earth together?"
Then she spoke a poem, saying:
"Alive, they never shared a house, //
But in death they had the same grave. //
'You thought that I had broken faith; //
I was true as the bright sun above.' " //
The ruler of Xi stopped her
but she would not listen.
Then she killed herself
and the rule of Xi killed himself too;
they died together on the same day.
The King of Chu praised this wife
as preserving her chastity and possessing righteousness.
Then he caused them to be buried together with the ceremonies for nobles.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: This wife rejoiced in doing good,
and therefore he told about her in a poem.
Now, righteousness moves the superior man
and profit moves the mean man;
the wife of the ruler of Xi was not moved by gain.
The Book of Songs says:
"In my reputation there is no flaw,
I am yours till death."
This could be said of her.- 80 -
The Song says:
Chu took captive the ruler of Xi
and the [King] took his wife into the palace to marry her.
The wife maintained herself firmly
and completed a long period without relaxing her fidelity.
She recited a poem, "The same Grave,"
and since she was mindful of the old husband, did not think of the new one.
For this reason, she died without great concern
and is placed in the biographies of the chaste and virtuous.
THE WIFE OF QI LIANG OF QI
She was the wife of Qi Liang Zhi of Qi.
While Duke Zhuang invaded Qu,
Zhi took part in the battle and died.
When Duke Zhuang was returning home,
he met his [i.e.,Zhi's] wife
and sent an officer to present his condolences to her on the road.
The wife of Qi Liang said,
"Now, if Zhi has committed any offense,
why should the ruler condescend to send me any message?
If he honors Zhi who has escaped committing any offence,
then I, the poor wife, still have the humble house of his father.
I would not dare to listen to any condolences in the fields.
On this account, Duke Zhuang turned back his cart, went to her house,
completed the ceremonies, and then left.
The wife of Qi Liang was childless;
in neither her husband's nor her mother's house had she any of the five degrees of relatives wearing mourning.
Thus she had no place to which she might turn
and she accompanied the corpse of her husband below the city wall and wept for him.
The wife's sincerity moved men
[so that] among those passed by, there was no one who did not wipe away his tears.
After ten days,
the city wall on this account fell down.
When she buried him,
she said,
"Where shall I go?
A wife should have some one to depend on.
While her husband is living, she depends on him;
while her husband is living, she depends on him;
and while her son is living, she depends on him.
Today, among the older relatives, I am without a father;
among those of the middle group, I am without husband;
and in the next generation, I am without a son.
In my husband's home I have no one to depend on
in order to manifest my sincerity;
in my mother's home I have no one to depend upon
to establish my observance of property.
How can I change to a second husband?
It will be just as good of I also die."
Afterwards she went to the Zi River and died [by drowning]
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The wife of Qi Liang was chaste and she understood the rules of propriety.
The Book of Songs says:
"That the mere glimpse of a plain coat // Could stab my heart with grief! //
Enough! Take me with you to your home. " //
This could be said of her.- í -
The Song says:
Qi Liang died in battle
and his wife was observing the mourning.
Duke Zhuang of Qi condoled with her on the road
but she turned aside and did not dare receive the condolence.
She wept for her husband at the city wall
and the wall fell down.
Considering that she had no relatives,
she went to the Zi River and died.
BO YING OF KING PING OF QU
Bo Ying
was the daughter of Duke Mu of Qin,
the wife of King Ping of Qu,
and the mother of King Zhao.
When King Zhao was on the throne,
Qu was fighting with Wu over Boqu
Wu was victorious over Qu
and thereafter entered Qu as far as Ying
but King Zhao escaped.
King Lu of Qu took all the wives of the harem
and then came to Bo Ying,
who took up a sword and said,
"I have learned
that the emperor
should be the model for all under heaven;
the duke
should be the exemplar for one state.
If the emperor disregards all regulations, then all under heaven will fall into disorder;
if a noble disregards the regulations, then the state is in danger.
The virtous conduct of husband and wife
is the firm beginning of man's relationships
and the origin of kingly instruction.
Therefore, to make clear the regulations of the king,
men and women are ordered in giving and receiving [articles] not to touch each other,
not to sit on the same mat,
not to eat from the same dish;
the [opposite] sexes
should not use the same clothes' rack and should use different towels and combs
so that they may avoid the arousing of dagerous affections.
If the nobles are licentious when away from home, exterminate them;
if the high ministers are licentious when away from home, banish them.
and if the scholars and common men are licentious when away from home punish them be castration
Now, on the other hand,
if benignity is lost, it can be restored by being righteous
and if rigtheousness is lost it can get restored by observing propriety.
To forget the [distinction between male and female
gives rise to rebellious ruin.
Now you have caused the beginning of disorders
which the nobles had repressed
and which the emperor had punished heavily.
At present, the King has cast aside the practice of correct deportment;
he has indulged the desires of disordered ruin;- ǐ -
and he has committed a matter for capital punishment.
How can you issue commands and instruct the people?
Moreover, I have learned
that it is not so good to live
while disgraced as to die while in honor.
If the King casts aside his principles,
he has no means to rule his country;
if I have licentious desires,
then there is no reason for me to remain alive in this world.
to have one husband is to be exalted, to have two husbands is to be disgraced;
[hence] I shall use death to preserve my chastity.
I do not dare accept your order.
Moreover, all you desire to get from me
is pleasure;
if you draw near to me, I will die.
What pleasure will you have,
if you first kill me?
Then what good is this to the King?
On this account the King was ashamed
and then withdrew.
He housed bo Ying with her governess and closed off the gate to the closed passage [to the women]s quarters]
and guarded it well by soldiers.
After a month,
Qins army arrived
and then Kina Zhao returned.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Bo Ying was brave, pure, and devoted to one [husband].
The Book of Songs says:
"Look at the foothills of Mount Han //
With hazel and redtorn so thick. //
Here' happiness to my lord, //
A happy quest for blessings." //
This could be said of her.- ǐ -
The Song says:
Ho Lu defeated Qu
and entered the palace
taking all the wives for his harem.
He was not afraid in battle
but Bo Ying protected hersef
[for] she was constant in her devotion for one [husband].
The Superior man praised her
as possessing chastity.
JIANG, THE CHASTE, OF ZHAO OF CHU
Jiang, the Chaste
was the daughter of a marquis of Qi
and the wife of King Zhao of Chu.
The king was going out on a pleasure trip
and he left his wife on the Qian Terrace and departed.
the king hearing that the river was rising,
sent an official to bring his wife away
but [the official] forgot to carry his seal of commission.
The official arrived
and asked the queen to come away,
but the wife replied,
"The King- ì -
has an agreement with his wife,
that if he gives orders to summon someone from the palace, he must use the seal of commission.
Now, the official does not carry the seal with him
[and so] I do not dare obey."
The official, taking leave, said
"Now, the river is rising very high
and if I return to get the seal,
I fear that it will be too late."
The wife said,
"I have learned
that the duty of the chaste woman is not to break an agreement;
the brave person does not fear to die.
I shall preserve this rule of chastity and that is all.
I know that if I follow the official I shall live;
if I remain, I must die.
But on the other hand, to break an agreement and violate righteousness
is not so good as to remain here and die.
Such being the case, the messenger went to bring the seal commission.
The the river rose very high,
the terrace crumbled,
and the wife was carried away by the flood and died.
The King said,
Ah, my wife!
in preserving righteousness, you died for a rule of chastity.
You would not trade life for an improper act;
you kept our agreement and maintained loyalty
in order to perfect your chastity."
Then he called her by the honorary title of "Jiang, the Chaste".
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Jiang, the Chaste, possessed the rules of wifehood.
The Book of Songs says:
"Good people, gentle folk- //
Their ways are faultless." //
This could be said of her.- ì -
The Song says:
Zhao of Qi went on a pleasure trip
and left Jiang on the Qian terrace.
The river's flood rose high
but without the seal of commission she would not leave.
The Queen kept the rule of chastity
and was carried away to her death without any fear.
The Superior Man narrated her story
and she is praised as matching Boji.
JI, THE CHASTE OF BAI OF CHU
Ji, the Chaste,
was the wife of Duke of Bai, [named] Sheng of Chu.
When the Duke of Bai died,
his wife twisted hempen thread [for a living] and did not remarry.
The King of Wu, having heard that she was beautiful and that her deportment was good,
sent a minister carrying a hundred i of money, and two pieces of white jade to invite her to marry him.
He used thirty curtained carriages to go to meet her
that she might become his wife.- 85 -
The minister brought her the presents
but the wife of Bai declined them, saying:
"While the Duke of Bai was living,
I, being fortunate, obtained the fulfillment of duties in the harem.
I held the comb and broom,
controlled the clothes and shoes,
and brushed the pillows and mats.
I was entrusted with the office of mate [to the ruler].
The Duke of Bai being unfortunate, died,
and I wished to care for his grave
in living out the years of my natural life.
Today, the King has presented [to me] betrothal gifts of money and jade
and the position of being the King's wife.
This is not what I, a foolish woman, have learned.
For thus, if one abandons righteousness and follows one's passions,
that is depravity;
if one sees gain and forgets the dead,
that is covetousness.
Now, what would the King
want of a depraved and covetous person?
I have learned
that the faithful minister does not lend his strength to other [rulers]
and the chaste woman does not lend her beauty to other men.
Why should I serve the living alone in this way
and the dead in another way?
Since I am not benign,
I cannot follow the dead.
Today, to go out again and be married,
would not that be too much?
Thereupon, she declined the presents and would not go.
The King of Wu praised her for preserving a chaste widowhood and possessing righteousness
and he gave her the honorary title of "Ji, the Chaste, of Chu."
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Ji, the Chaste, was moderate, continenet, honest, and faithful.
The wife's duty is important and the way is long;
benevolence consists in fulfilling one's duties
is this not also important?
After the [husband's] death, it is late,
but is it not also long?
The Book of Songs says:
'That lovely eldest Jiang, //
All that was told of her is true." //
This could be said of her.- 85 -
The Song says:
The wife of the Duke of Bai
preserved her widowhood and twisted thread [for living].
The king of Wu praised her
and used money and jade as presents.
The wife held her conduct constant
and though she would die, she would not change.
The Superior Man exalted her
and praised her excellent example.
THE TWO OBEDIENT ONES OF THE WEI CLAN- 86 -
The Two obedient Ones of the Wei clan
were the wife of King Ling and the chief concubine.
Qin destroyed the ruler of Wei
and then granted the fief to King Ling of an ancient and honorable family,
ordering him to offer his sacrifices.
King Ling died
and his wife was childless but she preserved her widowhood.
The chiefconcubine, who had a son,
was serving the wife of King Ling, and for eight years she did not falter
in caring for her with great diligence.
The wife spoke to the chief concubine, saying,
"You, child, have cared for me most diligently.
Your son has offered the ancestral sacrifices and you have served me;
I will not take advantage of it.
Moreover, I have learned that the mother of a prince does not act as a servant
and now, I am childless
and according to propriety
I ought to leave.
Now, again I am troubling you, child, by not changing my former position.
I am quite ashamed here in the home.
I desire to go to live outside;
and if we see each other from time to time,
I shall be very contented."
The chief concubine wept and replied, saying,
"The wife wishes the Ling family to receive a triple misfortune.
The husband's early demise
was the first misfortune;
that his wife was childless and the servant had a son,
was the second misfortune;
and the wife wishing to go and live outside [the home]
is the third misfortune.
I have learned that the faithful minister serves his prince without a moment of idleness or weariness;
the filial son sustains his parents without a day of vexation,
how can I, a servant, for the sake of a little honor change the observance of a servant?
To sustain carefully is the office of a constant servant;
how can the lady say that I am still diligent?"
The wife said,
"I am childless and disgrace you, the mother of a prince.
Although you desire me to act so,
still everyone will say that I do not understand propriety.
Finally, I desire to live outside [the home], and that is all."- 87 -
The chief concubine retired and spoke to her son, saying,
"I have learned that the Superior Man placed obedience
in the usages between superiors and inferiors
and in practicing the ceremonies of the ancients;
this is the way of obedience.
Today, since the wife has found my service troublesome,
she wishes to dwell outside,
and causes me to dwell in the home;
this is rebellion.
To act rebelliously and live
is not so good as to be obedient and die;
therefore, I wish to commit suicide."
Her son wept and restrained her
nor would he listen to her wishes.
the wife, hearing of this, feared,
and therupon, she promised the chief concubine to remain.
To the end of her days she cared for her, [i.e., the wife of King Ling] unfalteringly.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
"Two women mutually yielding to each other [the place of honor]
is truly royal conduct.
The Book of Songs says:
"My heart is not a stone //
It cannot be rolled."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The two obedient ones of the Wei Clan
maintained good conduct, both of them most firmly.
Though the servant's son replaced the heir,
she, [the servant], served the wife most faithfully as of old.
The wife of the lord was ashamed and yielded her place to her.
She sought to go outside the home to dwell
but in the end [the servant] would not listen to her
and the principle of propriety remained intact.
TAO YING, THE WIDOW OF LU
Tao ying
was the daughter of the family of Tao of [the state ]of Lu
She became a widow while yet young,
raised her orphaned children,
and since she was without strong brothers [to provide for her],
spun for a living.
A certain man of Lu heard about her righteousness
and was about to seek her in marriage.
Ying, having heard about it,
feared that she could not avoid him,
and sang a song
to make clear that she would not change to a second husband.
Her song said,
The yellow snow-goose was early widowed
and for seven years it did not mate.
It hid its head alone in passing the night
and did not go about with the rest of its kind.- 88 -
During half of the night it called forth sadly
as it thought of its former mate.
Since it was Heaven's will that I should become a widow quite early,
what harm is it for me to pass the night alone?
The widowed wife thinks of the husband
and her tears fall as she recalls his actions.
Alas, alas!
the dead cannot be forgotten.
If the bird is estimable,
how much more so a chaste and good person.
Although one may find a worthy mate,
to the end one does not marry a second time."
When the man of Lu heard this he said,
"This woman can not be obtained [in marriage].
Afterwards he did not again seek her
and the widow, Ying,
did not alter her purpose during her whole life.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Tao Ying was chaste, single-hearted and thoughtful.
The Book of Songs says:
"It is my heart's sadness //
that makes me chant and sing." //
this could be said of her.- 88 -
The Song says:
When Tao Ying was widowed early in life,
she spun thread and raised her children.
Someone wished to marry her
but she regulated her conduct
and sang a song to explain her deportment.
The suitor then ceased [to beseech her].
The Superior Man commended her
and used her story of an honorable woman..
GAO XING, THE WIDOW OF LIANG
Gao Xing
was a widowed wife from the country of Liang.
She was glorious in her beauty and praiseworthy in her concuct.
Though her husband died, leaving her widowed early in life,
yet she did not remarry.
The noblemen of Liang strove among themselves, for they desired to marry her
but could not win her.
The king of Liang heard of this
and sent his minister with bethrothal gifts.
Gao Xing said,
"My husband was unfortunate and died young
so as to fill a grave before the dogs and horses.- 89 -
I will care for and raise the tender young orphans,
but I have not gained
my special intent [of following my husband to the grave].
Though many honorable men have sought me,
I was unfortunate and succeeded in evading them
and today the King would remarry me.
I have learned
that the principle of the wife is
that once having gone forth to marry, she will not change over,
that she may keep all the rules of chaste loyalty.
To deliberate on forgetting the dead and to run to the living
is not loyalty;
to be honored and forget the lowly
is not chastity;
and to reject righteousness and follow gain
is not worthy of a man."
Then she took a mirror and grasping a knife, cut off her nose, saying,
I thus punish myself
but so that i shall not die
and so will not allow the childeren to be orphaned a second time.
The King has sought me
because of my beauty
but today, I have disfigured what is left of my person
that thus the danger might be dissipated."
Thereupon, the minister made his report
an the king exalted her righteousness
and praised her conduct.
He restored her liberty
an honored her with the title of "Gao Xing".
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Gao Xing was chaste, decorous, single-hearted, and pure.
The Book of Songs says:
"You thought I had broken faith; //
I was true as the bright sun above." //
this could be said of her.- 89 -
The Song says:
Gao Xing, who dwelt in Liang,
was chaste, single-hearted, and pure.
She did not covet rising to honor,
and her duty was in being faithful to one husband.
She did not accept the betrothal gifts of Liang
but cut off her nose to disfigure her body.
The Superior Man exalted her
and manifested her example to later generations.
THE FILIAL WIFE, THE WIDOW OF THE COUNTRY OF CHEN
The filial Wife was a young widowed wife [of the country] of Chen.
She was married at the age of sixteen
and as yet had no children
when her husband had to go to the frontier post.- 90 -
Moreover, as her husband was leaving,
he enjoined his wife, saying,
"Wether I shall live or die, I do not know;
I am blessed with an old mother
but I am without the assistance of any brothers;
therefore, If I do not return,
are you willing to care for my mother?"
She answered,
"I promise."
The husband having really died there, did not return,
and the wife sustained the mother-in-law unremittently.
Her love for her mother-in-law was evermore constant;
she spun thread as her home employment;
and she had no intention of remarrying.
When she had maintained her mourning for three years,
her father and mother pitied her as she was young, childless, and early widowed.
Her parents were about to take her home to remarry her
but the Filial Wife said,
"I have learned
that loyalty is the business of man
and that righteousness is the rule of conduct.
I fortunately obtained the favor of leaving my swaddling baby clothes;
I have received orders from my parents; and I have served a husband.
Moreover, when my husband was departing,
he entrusted me with his aged mother
and at that time I promised him [to care for her].
If you receive a trust from men,
how can you neglect it?
To neglect a trust is disloyal;
to turn your back on the dead is not righteous;
such things may not be done."
The mother said,
I pitied your tender years and early widowhood."
The Filial Wife said,
"I would prefer to be recorded among the righteous and die
than to be recorded among mean persons and live.
Moreover, I am caring for my husband's aged mother and cannot leave her.
If one consents by promise to men and proves not trustworthy,
how can one establish her place in this world?
I was a man's wife,
constantly supporting my aged mother-in-law;
my husband was unfortunate and died
without fulfilling his duty as a filial son;
Today, you would order me to leave [his home]
and not to care for his aged mother;
this would make it clear that I am not fitted for my husband and manifest me as lacking in filial piety.
To be unfilial, to be unfaithful, amd moreover, to lack righteousness,
how can I live?
For this reason I desire to kill myself."
Her father and mother were greatly alarmed and did not care to give her in marriage [again].
Thereafter they ordered her to care for her mother-in-law
who died after twenty eight years.
She buried her
and to the end of her days offered up the sacrifices to the dead.
The Prefect of Huaiyang caused her to be known - 91 -
and the Emperor Xiaowen praised her righteousness,
honored her loyalty,
and exalted her conduct.
He sent an official to present her with forty catties of gold,
established her liberty through life,
and gave her the nonorable title, "Filial Wife."
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Filial Wife was perfect in the principles of wifehood.
The Book of Songs says:
"Those are men indeed! //
They hold hearts that are staunch and true." //
This could be said of her.- 91 -
The Song says:
The filial Wife lived in Chen
ad her husband died while she was childless.
Her mother would have married her off
but to the end she would not listen to her mother.
She gave her undivided attention to supporting her mother-in-law,
for once having performed the marriage rite, she did not change.
The emperor praised her
and honored her with the title, "Filial Wife."
THE RIGHTEOUS NURSE OF DUKE XIAO OF LU
The Righteous Nurse of Xiao
was the nurse of Duke Xiao, named Cheng,
and the widow of the Zang family
In the beginning
Duke Xiao's father, Duke Wu, together with his two sons, the eldest son, Gua, and the middle son Xi, were at the court of King Xuan of Zhou.
King Xuan appointed Xi as her heir apparent of Lu,
and when Duke Wu died,
Xi was established
in his place as Duke Yi.
Duke Xiao at that time was called the Duke's son, Cheng,
and he was the youngest.
The Righteous Nurse together with her own son entered the palace
and she nursed the duke's son, Cheng.
The son of Gua, Boyu, together with some men of Lu, having started a rebellion,
attacked and killed Duke I and himself took the throne.
He sought the Duke's son, Cheng, in the palace
that he might kill him
but when Righteous Nurse heard that Boyu would kill Cheng,
she dressed her own son as if he were Cheng
and left him lying in Cheng's place.
Boyu killed him
and thereupon the Righteous Nurse went out carrying Cheng in her arms.
She passed Cheng's maternal uncle, who was Lu's minister abroad,
and the uncle asked if Cheng were dead.
The Righteous Nurse said,
"He is not dead;
he is here."
The uncle asked,
"How was he able to escape?"
The Righteous Nurse said,
"I used my own son to replace him."
And after this the Righteous Nurse escaped.
[When Boyu had been duke] for eleven years,
the ministers of Lu, who all knew that Cheng was with the nurse,
therefore besought the Emperor of Zhou to kill Boyu and establish Cheng
as Duke Xiao.
The people of Lu rejoiced at this.
The Lun Yu says,
"Suppose that there is an individual who can be entrusted with the charge of a young orphan prince."
This could be said of the Righteous Nurse.
The Song says:
Boyu started a rebellion
and commenced at the palace of Lu.
The nurse of Duke Xiao,
mother of the Zang family,
escaped and hid duke Xiao
by exchanging him for her own son.
The nurse being like this
was also sincere enough to be depended upon.
MOU OF ZHENG, WIFE OF KING CHENG OF CHU
Mou of Zheng, nee Ying
was a maid-in-waiting of a woman of Zheng
ad the wife of King Cheng of Chu.
In the beginning King Cheng, having ascended a terrace,
was looking down on the palace of the harem
and all the women of the palace turned their heads to look up.
Zimou kept walking straight ahead and did not look at him;
her pace was sedate and she did not alter it.
The king said,
"You, walking there, look here!"
Zimou did not look.
The King said,
"Look at me
and I shall raise you to be my regal wife."
Still Zimou did not look.
The king said,
"Look at me
and moreover, I shall give you a thousand pieces of money and give your father and brothers to the nobility."
Zimou continued on without looking up.
On this account, the king descended from the terrace and asked her, saying,
"The place of my wife
is very honorable;
the salary
a noble is very generous;
by one glance you could have gained them
but you continued not to look.
How is this?
Zimou said,
"I have learned that the women's deportment is sedate and gracious.
At present
the great King was on his terrace and if I had looked up,
then I should have broken the rules of propriety;
therefore, I did not look up.
If I looked up after having been told of the possibility of receiving honors, of being the King's wife,
and of the grant of nobility,
then I should have been covetous of honor.
If I should have taken pleasure in gain,I would thus have forgotten my principles.
How could I serve the King?"
The king said,
"Excellent!"
and afterwards raised her up to be his wife.
They lived on for almost a year
and the king was about to established the Duke's son, Shangchen, as crown prince.
The king asked Zishang,the chief minister, about him
and Zishang said,
"Your lordship is not yet old
and has many favorite sons;
if you establish this one now and later degrade him,- 95 -
you certainly sill cause a rebellion.
Moreover, this man has the eyes of a wasp and the voice of a wolf;
he is a severe man
an may not be given the position."
The king retired and asked his wife about it.
Zimou said,
"The words of the chief minister are loyal and may be followed.
The King did not accept her advice
and afterwards raised him [Shangchen] to that position.
Later on Shangchen employed Zishang to rescue the affairs of Cai; then Shangchen slandered and killed him.
Zimou spoke with her nurse saying,
"I have learned that the business of the woman is to attend to the kitchen
only, however,
what my heart observes,
I cannot keep hidden away.
Now,
formerly Zishang remarked that the Crown Prince could not be raised to that position;
the Crown Prince disliked him,
vilified him, and killed him.
The King did not examine the case well
and judged that there was a fault where there was no fault;
this is to turn black into white
and to mistake the top for the bottom.
The King had many favorite sons,
all of whom wished to obtain the kingdom
but the Crown Prince coveted it fiercely
and feared to lose his position.
The King again did not understand
and I am without means of making it clear.
The sons of the concubines will fight the sons of the legal wife
and calamity will be rife."
Afterwards the king wished to establish [as Heir Apparent] the Duke's son, Zhi,
who was the brother of Shangchen by a concubine.
Zimou withdrew and spoke to her nurse saying,
"I have learned that loyalty does not permit suspicion.
Today, th King must change the Heir Apparent to Zhi
and I fear that this will be the cause of a ruinous rebellion,
so I spoke to the King.
The King did not answer me.
Is not his considering the Heir Apparent not to be my son,
a suspicion that I am slandering him?
To be the object of suspicion and live,
though all men know its falsity,
that is the same as to live without righteousness.
It is best to die and make the case clear.
Moreover, when the King hears that I have died,
he must understand that he cannot remove the Heir Apparent, [ i.e.,Shangchen]."
Thereafter she committed suicide
and the nurse caused her words to reach the king.
At that time the Crown Prince knew that the king wished to depose him- 96 -
so then he raised up troops for a rebellion
and they surrounded the king's palace.
The king begged to eat a pear's paw and die
but he could not obtain it
an thereafter committed suicide.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
If one has not obtained to benignity，
who can use his own person as a warning?
The Book of Songs says:
"[That great gentleman] // Would give his life rather than fail his lord." //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Zimou early learned
to maintain her principles perseveringly;
she rose in rank by not looking [at the king]
and in the end was King Cheng's consort.
She knew the disorder of Shangchen
and spoke strongly of it.
She herself being suspected of not having her own son as the Heir Apparent
used her own death to make clear her innocence.
HUAI YING OF YU OF QIN
Huai Ying
was the daughter of Duke Mu of Qin
and the wife of Yu, the eldest son of Duke Hui of Jin.
Yu was a hostage in Qin
and Duke Mu gave him Ying as his wife.
After six years,
Yu, who was about to escape and return [home],
spoke to the Lady Ying, saying,
"I have been away from my country for a number of years;
the relation between son and father is forgotten
and the dealings of Qin and Jin have not added new relationships.
Now the birds return to their old abodes;
when the fox is dying he turns towards his native hill;
and I shall turn toward Jin and die.
Will you go with me, then?"
The Lady Ying replied,
"You
are the heir apparent of Jin
and are in disgrace in Qin;
and so you desire to go.
Is it not befitting?
Although
my own ruler has ordered me to wait on you, holding your towel and comb, to ensure your stay,
still I am not now sufficient to bind you to us.
This is because I am unfitted [for you].
If I follow you in returning to Jin,
I abandon my own lord;
if I report your plan to my lord,
that would violate the righteousness of wifehood.
Of three lines of action, no one is permissible to me.
Although I do not follow you,
you may go
for I do not dare divulge your words
nor do I dare follow you."
Zi Yu thereupon escaped and returned to Jin.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Huai Ying was excellent in fulfilling the life of husband and wife.- 97 -
The Song says:
Yu of Jin was a hostage in Qin
and was married to Huai Ying.
Yu was about to escape
and Huai Ying was not willing to follow him,
nor would she divulge his words.
She controlled her heart very evenly
and did not tell anyone who might follow him
for she was without bias in this [matter]
YUE JI OF KING ZHAO OF CHU
Yue Ji of Zhao of Chu
was the daughter of King Jujien of Yue
an the wife of King Zhao of Chu.
King Zhao was on a pleasure trip
and Cai Ji was on his left
and Yue Ji formed the third on his right.
The king liked to travel in a four horse chariot in order to go swiftly.
Soon afterwards they ascended the Fu She terrace
in order to look out on the Yun Meng Garden
and to watch the officers and ministers driving on.
Then he was happy and turning to the two queens, he said,
"Is it not pleasant?"
Cai Ji replied,
"It is pleasant."
The king said,
"I wish thus to live;
will you also die thes with me?"
The Lady Ying replied,
"You are the heir apparent of Jin
and are in disgrace in Qin;
and so you desire to go.
Is it not befitting?
Although
my own ruler has ordered me to wait on you, holding your towel and comb, to ensure your stay,
still I am not now sufficient to bind you to us.
This is because I am unfitted [for you].
The king looked at the historian and said, "Record that!"
Cai Ji has promised to follow in death!"
Then he spoke the same words to Yue Ji
but she replied,
"When we have pleasure, let us rejoice,
but it cannot be for long."
The king said,
"I desire to live thus with you
and to die with you;
can I not obtain it?"
Yue Ji replied, saying,
"Formerly your ancestor, King Zhuang, was given to licentious pleasures and for three years
he did not attend to affairs of state.
At last he was able to correct himself
an in the end ruled all the feudal princes.
I would like to see you, my lord, imitate your ancestors,
that is, change from the love of pleasure to being diligent in the affairs of state.
Thus far it has been otherwise
and you wish me to die for you;
how can you obtain this?
Moreover, the King used white silk to tie up his horses and chariot and married me in my own district;
my ruler received the [mariage] presents in the ancestral temple
but made no agreement that I would die [with you].
I have learned that all the aunts and wives consider
that death displays the perfection of the ruler
and that it increases regard for him;
I have not learned that a hasty following of his dark death is glorious.
I do not dare obey your order."
On this account the king
understood and respected Yue Ji's words
but he still was partial to Cai Ji.
They dwelt together for twenty-five years
and once as the king was coming to the aid of Chen,
the two queens accompanied him.
The king became ill in the camp
and a red cloud hovered over the sun
as if it were a bird on the wing.
The king inquired form the Historian of Zhou about it
and the Historian said,
"It signifies harm to the King's person,
but it can be transferred to the generals or ministers."
The generals and ministers heard of this
and were about to ask to use their persons as a sacrifice to the spirit.
The king said,
"The generals and the ministers of the King are the limbs of his body;
now, if we pass the misfortune to them,
how shall it avoid my person?"
Then he would not listen to them.
Yue Ji said,
"Magnificent!
The virtue of the King causes me
to wish to follow him [in death].
On that former day of the pleasure trip, he enjoyed lewd pleasures
and so caused me not to dare to promise [to die with him].
Now, when he has returned to propriety,
all of the men of the kingdom would die for the King;
how much more so would I do so!
Please, I desire to go ahead to expel the fox of Hades [for you]."
The king said,
"Formerly, when I was taking a pleasure trip,
I was only jesting;
for if should die,
then that would manifest my lack of virtue."
Yue Ji said,
"On that former day, although I did not let the words out of my mouth,
in my heart I vowed it then.
I have learned that the loyal on is not ungrateful
and that the righteousness one does not establish his works falsely.
I will die for the righteousness of the King;
I will not die for the pleasure of the King."
After this she killed herself.
The king became gravely ill
and wanted to cede the throne to his three younger brothers
bu they would not acpuiesce.- 99 -
The King died amidst his army
and Cai Ji in the end was unable to die.
The King's younger brother, Zily, consulted together with Zixi and Xiqi, saying,
"The mother [i.e., Yue Ji]was loyal;
the son must be benign."
They then concealed [the King's death] from the army and cut off communications abroad;
they sent for the son of Yue Ji, Xiong Zhang,
and enthroned him as King Hui.
Afterwards he dismissed the army to return and bury King Zhao.
The man of Noble Sentiments says: Yue Ji's loyalty could cause her to die for righteousness.
The Book of Songs says:
"In my reputation there is no flaw, //
I am yours till death." //
This could be said of Yue Ji.
The Song says:
King Zhao of Chu was on a pleasure trip
and wanted his queens to die with him.
Cai Ji promised the king
but Yue Ji maintained propriety.
In the end she alone died on principle
and all the ministers exalted and praised her.
And so of these two queens,
her virtue was incomparable.
THE WIFE OF THE GENERAL OF GAI
She was the wife of Qiuzi, the general of the chariots of Gai.
The [army] of Rong invaded Gai
an killed its ruler.
[Rong] issued an order to all the courtiers of Gai saying,
"If anyone dares to commit suicide,
his wife and children will be punished by death."
Qiuzi tried to kill himself
but others saved him
and he did not succeed in dying.
When he returned,
his wife spoke to him saying,
"I have learned that the principles of a general are to be brave and not to enjoy life.
On this account the officers and the common people expend their strength and do not fear to die;
on this reason the outcome of the battle is victory and the capture of the enemy takes place;
for this reason they can preserve their country and give peace to their ruler.
When one fights a battle and forgets bravery,
he is not filial;
if the ruler perishes and he does not die,
he is not faithful.
Now the army was defeated and the ruler died;
how is it that you alone are alive?
Fidelity and filial piety have perished in your person.
How can you bear to come back here?"
Qiuzi said,
"Gai is small and Rong is large;
my strength at last was exhausted.
Our ruler was unfortunate and died
bu I seriously tried to commit suicide;
others restrained me
and I did not succeed in dying."
His wife said,
"If on that former day, someone restrained you,
now what is there that still stops you?"- 100 -
Qiuzi said,
"I do not love my life
but the people of Rong issued an order saying, 'For the one who commits suicide, punishment by death to his wife and children.' On this account I did not die.
Supposing that I had died, what profit would it have been for my ruler?"
The wife said,
"I have learned
that if the sovereign be sad, the minister should be disgraced;
if the sovereign be disgraced, the minister should die;
and at present, the sovereign is dead and you are not dead.
Can this be called righteousness?
Many are killing the officers and the people;
you cannot save the country, and you are still alive.
Can this be called benignity?
You love your wife and children, and forget benignity and righteousness;
you betray your former ruler and serve a powerful and cruel enemy.
Can this be called loyalty?
A man without the conduct of a loyal minister and without the deportment of benignity and righteousness,
can such one be called accomplished?
The Annals of Zhou say,
'The sovereign comes before the minister;
the father and mother before the wife and children.'
'To care for you wife
is a private interest;
to serve your sovereign
is a public duty.
Today, for the sake of your wife,
you have neglected the regulations of a minister.
You have failed in the service of your fuler;
you have cast aside the public duty of a minister;
and you have glorified the private love for your wife.
You have stolen your life and you are alive unjustly.
how much more so
should you be ashamed!
I cannot bear this shame together with you and live."
Thereafter she committed suicide
The ruler of Rong praised her,
sacrificed an ox for her,
and buried her with ceremonies.
He presented her younger brother with a hundred i of money,
employed him as a minister,
and ordered another to rule over Gai.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The wife of the genreal of Gai was pure-hearted and loved righteousness.
The book of Songs says:
"That good man, my lord-"
In his power no flaw."
This could be said of her.
The song says:
The wife of the general of Gai
maintained her principles and was skilled in repartee.
When Rong destroyed Gai,
Qiuzi alone was left alive
and his wife was ashamed that he had not died.
she narrated in order the five glories
and died before her husband.
In the end she left an illustrious name.
THE PUBLIC SPIRITED AUNT OF LU- 101 -
The Public Spirited Aunt of Lu
was a woman from the countryside of Lu.
Qi's soldiers were going to attack Lu and when they reached the borderlands,
they saw a woman
carrying a child in her arms
and leading [another] one as she hurried along.
Now when the army was drawing near to her,
she cast down the child she was carrying,
took in her arms the one she was leading, and went on up the hill.
The child followed her and cried out
bu the woman kept on going and did not look.
The commander of Qi's army asked the child, saying
"Is that person who is running away, your mother?"
He said,
"It is."
"Whom is your mother carrying?"
He said,
"I don't know."
Qi's commander then pursued her
and an officer drew his bow and was about to shoot her with an arrow,
when he cried out,
"Stop!
If you don't stop,
I shall shoot you."
The woman then turned back
ad Qi's commander asked who the child was that she was carrying
and who was the one that she had cast aside.
She replied, saying,
"The one I was carrying is my older brother's son
and the one I cast aside is my own.
When I saw the army drawing near,
sice I had not sufficient strength to save both of them,
I cast aside my own son."
The commander of Qi said,
"The relation of a son to his mother
is that she loves him
and that that love is deep in her heart.
Today, you put him from you
and carried the son of your brother.
how is that?"
The woman said,
"[To save] my brother's child
is a work of private love,
but [to save] my brother's child
is a public duty.
Now, if I turn my back on a public duty, I turn to my private love;
if I abandon my brother's child to die to save my own child,
and by good fortune should I escape,
still thus my sovereign will not tolerate me;
the officials will not tolerate me;
and my compatriots will not live with me.
If that were the case,
then I should have no place that would harbor my body
and my tired feet would be without ground to tread upon.
Although it is painful to lose my son
and act righteously,
how should I alone speak of duty?
I cannot live in the state commander of Lu and be lacking in righteousness."
On this account, the commander of Qi halted his troops and stopped there.
He sent a messenger to speak to the King of Qi, saying,
"Lu cannot be attacked now,
for when we had reached the borderland,
a woman of the hills and bogs
was so intelligent in maintaining her principles, performing her duty,
and in not allowing a private love to harm a public good,
that [I thought] how much more [public spirited] must be the ministers and knights of the court.
We ask to return."
The ruler of Qi permitted them to do so.
The ruler of Lu, having heard of this,
rewarded the woman with a hundred pieces of silk,- 102 -
and gave herthe title of the "Public Spirited Aunt."
The Man of noble Sentiments says;
The Public Spirited Aunt was upright and loyal
She truly put righteousness into practice
and moreover, her righteousness was great.
Although she was just a common woman,
the country still depended upon her.
How much more should we use propriety and righteousness to rule the nation.
The Bool of Songs says:
"Valid are the works of inward power;
In all the lands men will conform to them."
This could be said of her.- 102 -
The Song says:
The ruler of Qi was attadking Lu.
the Public Spirited Aunt maintained right principles,
for she cast aside her own son and carried her nephew in her arms.
The leader of Qi's army asked her about it
and praised her for reasoning from principle.
Since one woman was so righteous,
thereafter the army of Qi halted.
THE LADY NEE ZHAO, WIFE OF THE KING OF DAI
The Lady nee Zhao,
wife of the King of Dai
was the daughter of Zhao Jianzi, the eldest sister of Xiangzi,
and the wife of the King of Dai.
When Jianzi was buried,
and Xiangzi had not yet put off his clothes of mourning,
he mounted the spacious hall for an audience.
He beguiled the King of Dai
to order the cook to carry a ladle to serve the king's food.
When his followers were serving [the soup,
Xiangzi] secretly ordered the stewards who were carrying ladles to attack and kill the King of Dai and his followers.
thereupon he raised an army and subdued the land of Dai. He went forth to meet his sister, the lady of Zhao,
but the lady said,
"I received orders from my former Lord to serve the King of Cai.
Today, when more than ten years have passed,
though Dai had given no great cause to provoke you,
yet you, the ruler, have killed him.
Dai has already gone to ruin;
do you think that I am about to return with you?
Moreover, I have learned
that a wife maintains righteousness by not marrying a second husband;
how should I have two husbands?- 103 -
If I shall use my younger brother to insult my husband,
that is not righteousness.
If I use my younger brother to be avenged for my husband,
that is not benignity.
I do not like to be hateful
and on the other hand neither shall I return with you."
Thereafter she wept sadly and called on Heaven.
She committed suicide at the place called Moji
and the people of Dai all cherished her memory.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Zhao, the wife, fulfilled perfectly the duties of marriage.
The Book of Songs says:
"Never usurp or go beyond your rights,
And few will not take you as their model."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Consider Zhao Xiangzi,
the younger brother of the wife of Dai
who surprised and exterminated the King of Dai.
He went forth to meet his elder sister to take her home [as wife]
but the elder sister brought forward righteous principles
and stated clearly the rules of chastity and propriety.
She would neither return with him nor show hatred towards him;
thereafter, she remained in the wilderness to die.
THE RIGHTEOUS STEPMOTHER OF QI
The Righteous Stepmother of Qi
was the mother of two sons of Qi.
When Xuan was king,
there was a man who died in a fight on the road
and the magistrate was examining the case.
[The dead man] had received one wound
while two brothers were standing by his side
and so the magistrate questioned them.
The older brother said,
"I did it."
And the younger brother said,
"It was not my older brother,
therefore I killed him."
After a year
the magistrate could not reach a decision
and he spoke to the minister about it
but the minister could not decide it
and he spoke to the king about it.
The king said,
If I pardon [both] of them, today,
I shall allow a criminal to go free;
if i kill [both] of them
I shall execute and innocent man.
I judge that their mother is able to know their good and evil
and we shall learn by questioning the mother
and listening to which one she wants killed and to [which one ] to live."
The minister summoned the mother and examined her saying,
"Mother, your sons have killed a man
and the older and younger each wish to die in place of the other.
The magistrate could not decide the case
and referred it to the king
but since the king is benign and kind,
he asks the mother which one she wants to live."
The mother wept sadly and replied, saying,
"Kill the younger one!"- 104 -
The minister, having heard her reply,
on account of it, asked her,
"Now, the youngest son
is the one whom men usually love most
and at present you want him killed.
How is that?"
The mother replied, saying,
"The younger son
is my own;
the older son
is the previous wife's son.
When the father took ill and was dying,
he ordered me saying,
'Raise him well and look after him,'
and I said,
'I promise.'
Now, when you receive a trust from someone
and you have accepted it by a promise,
how can you forget such a trust and not be true to that promise?
Moreover, to kill the older brother and let the younger brother live,
is to cast aside a public duty for a private love;
to make false one's words and to forget loyalty
is to cheat the dead.
If words are meaningless and
promises are not distinguished [from non-promises],
how can I dwell on this earth?
The Man of noble Sentiments says: The Righteous Mother was loyal and liked uprighteousness.
She restrained her actions and could yield to others.
The Book of Songs says:
"All happiness to our lord, //
A model to all lands."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The Righteous Stepmother was loyal, honest, equitable,
and understood propriety.
Her own sons pretended to be guilty
and they mutually cede [freedom] to each other
without ceasing so that the magistrate could not decide the case.
The king caused the mother to be examined
and she clung to her trust and acted righteously.
In the end both sons escaped punishment.
THE CHASTE WIFE OF QIU OF LU
The Chaste Wife
was the wife of Qiu of Lu.
When she had been married but five days,
her husband went to fill an office in Chen
and after five years, then returned.
When he had not yet reached his home,
he saw a woman by the roadside picking mulberries.
Qiu Huzi was pleased with her
and he descended from his carriage and spoke to her, saying,
"As it is very hot to pick mulberries
and I have come a long journey, I desire you to allow me to eat in the shade of the mulberry tree and to spread out my cloak to rest."
The woman went on picking mulberries without stopping
and [again] Qiu Huzi spoke to her saying,
"To labor in the field is not so good as to happen on one good harvest;
to pick mulberries is not so good as visiting with the minister of the state.
I have no money
that I desire to give you."
The woman said,
Oh no!
I use my strength to pick mulberris;
I spin and weave in order to supply clothes and food;
and I serve my parents-in-law
and raise my parents children.
I do not want men's money;
I had hoped that the minister would have no ulterior motive;
and also I have no intention of giving in to lust.
Take up your travelling cloak and your money!
After this, Qiu Zi departed.
When he reached home
he presented the money to his mother
and she ordered someone to call his wife to come.
Then the woman who was picking mulberries approached
and Qiu Hizi was ashamed.
The wife said,
"You bound up your hair,
bade farewell to your parents, and went to your official post.
When it was time to visit your relatives, you came quickly,
raising a dust, and hurrying to arrive.
Today, you took a fancy to a woman by the roadside,
threw down your cloak,
and would have given her your money.
This is to forget your mother
and to forget your mother is unfilial.
To like the beauty of women and to give in to unrestrained lust,
is depraved conduct.
Depraved conduct is not righteous.
If you are unfilial in the service of your sovereign;
you will be disloyal in the service of your sovereign;
if your home life is not righteous,
then the administration of your office will be unprincipled.- 106
Filial piety and benignity have both gone to ruin
and this may not be allowed.
I cannot bear to see
you take another wife;
neither can I marry again."
Afterwards she departed and went towards the East
were she cast herself into a river and was drowned.
The man of Noble Sentiments says:
The Chaste Wife was great in goodness,
while her husband was unfilial nor had he a great love for his parents or for other people.
The Book of Songs says:
"Only she is mean,
That is why I make this stab."
This could be said of him.
The Song says:
Qiu was in the west in an official post
and after five years returned [home].
He met his wife but did not recognize her
but while in his heart he had lustful intentions,
the wife maintained her devotion to one [husband].
he returned to his home and they recognized each other.
The shame-faced husband was without righteousness
late Western Han
After two years, when he was returning home,
his wife was having a love affair with a neighbor
and she feared that Zhu Fu might learn of it.
Her lover was frightened
but the wife said,
"Do not be afraid
for I have sealed up some poison wine
in order to serve it to him."
Three days later
Zhu Fu arrived
and his wife said,
"I have been working for you;
I have sealed up some wine to serve you."
She sent the maid servant to get the wine and bring it in.
The maid servant knew in her heart that the wine was poisoned
and she thought within herself, "If I take in the wine, then I shall kill Zhu fu
and that is not righteous;
if I speak of it, I also shall kill my mistress
and that is not loyal. What shall I do?"
She pretended to fall and throw down the wine
[at which] Zhu Fu was angry and beat her.- 107 -
When he had finished,
the wife, fearing that the maid servant might tell on her,
had her beaten still more, for she hoped that she might kill her.
The maid servant knew that she was about to die
and [yet] to the end would not speak.
The younger brother of Zhu fu had learned of the whole affair
and told all to Zhu Fu.
Zhu Fu, being frightened,
then freed the maidservant
and beat his wife to death.
He sent a man to inquire of the maid servant secretely, saying,
"You knew of this whole affair.
Why did you not speak of it
but on the contrary chanced death?"
The maid servant said,
"Why kill my mistress so that I, myself, should live
and yet have disgraced the name of my mistress?
If I had died, there would only have been my death.
Why should I have spoken of it?"
Zhu Fu praised her righteousness,
honored her good intention,
and wished to receive her into his home as his [legal] wife.
The maid servant excused herself, saying,
"My mistress is disgraced and has died, and only I, the servant am alive;
in this I am lacking propriety.
If I take the place of my mistress,
I should rebel against propriety.
Of these two faults .i.e. to be lacking in propriety, and to rebel against propriety, I have committed one.
If today I commit both of them,
it will be difficult for me to remain alive."
She wished to kill herself.
Zhu Fu having learned of it,
then gave her rich gifts, and would marry her [to someone else.]
All the neighbors vied with each other to marry her.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Faithful Maid Servant was kind and generous.
since her fame was of the slightest, she did not make the matter known;
Though her conduct was without anything hidden, yet it was not made manifest.
The Book of Songs says:
"There can be nothing said that has not its answer, //
No need of Power that has not its reward." //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The Faithful servant of Zhu of Zhou
was kind, gracious, and orderly.
Zhu's wife was licentious secretely
and she put medicine into the wine to poison Zhu [her husband].
She ordered the maid servant to present and take it in.
The maid servant pretended to trip in order to remove the harm
and she was entirely loyal to her mistress.
In the end she received her reward.
THE VIRTOUS NURSE OF WEI
The Virtous Nurse of Wei
was the nurse of a prince ofWei.
Qin attacked Wei
and defeated her;
then killed King Xia of Wei
and punished by death all of the sons of the king,- 108 -
but one young son was not taken.
They issued a decree to the state of Wei, saying,
"To the one who captures the young prince,
a reward of 1000 "i" of money;
for the one who hides him,
punishment even to the extermination of his family."
The Virtous Nurse fled together with the young prince
and a former minister of Wei saw the nurse and recognized her. He said,
"Is the nurse devoid of goodness?"
The nurse said,
"Alas,
what can I do for the prince?"
The former minister said,
"Where is the prince now?
I have heard the edict of Qin saying,
'For the one who can take the prince,
a reward of 1000 "i" of money;
for the one who conceals him,
punishment even to the extermination of his family.'
If the nurse would tell [Qin] about him,
she could obtain a thousand pieces of money;
if she knows and does not tell,
then her brothers will be without descendants."
The nurse said,
"Alas!
I do not know where the prince is living."
The former minister said,
"I have heard that the nurse and the prince escaped together."
The nurse said,
Although I know where he is,
I could never tell it."
The former minister of Wei said,
"Today, the state of Wei is already defeated
and the ruined clan is already wiped out.
For whose sake
are you concealing him?"
The nurse sighed sadly and said,
"To behold gain and turn against one's superior
is rebellion;
to fear death and cast away righteousness is chaos.
is rebellion;
Today, you uphold rebellion and chaos in order to seek gain;
I will not do so.
Moreover, all who nourish men's children have a duty to keep them alive
and not kill them.
How can profit be a reward for the one who fears the cause of its punishment?
That would be to cast aside honesty and righteousness and to act contrary to principle;
I cannot live and be the occasion of the prince's capture."
Thereafte she took up the prince in her arms and fled to the deep bogs.
The former minister told this to the soldiers of Qin
and they pursued her and saw her.
They were striving to hit her with arrows
and the nurse used her own body to shield the young prince.
Several tens of arrows fixed themselves in her body
and she died together with the young prince.
When King Min returned to the palace, he saw all the ladies
and anounced to them,
"Today, I went on a pleasure trip
and I obtained a very virtous woman
who will arrive today and will replace all of you."
They all wondered at this, put on their best dresses,
and stood awaiting her arrival.
Su of the Goitre
was abashed
and all the ladies of the palace put their sleeves over their mouths and laughed;
the bystanders lost countenance
and could not control themselves.
The King of Qin heard of it
and honored her because she maintained loyalty and died for righteousness.
Then he gave her a funeral with the rites of nobility
and had a bull sacrificed for her.
he conferred favors on her elder brother as Wu Tai Fu
and presented him with a hundred "i" of money.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Virtous Nurse was benign and generous.
She valued righteousness greatly and esteemed wealth lightly.
This was her etiquette:
In choosing the mothers
and those to be trusted for the children's room of the palace- 109 -
she sought for liberality and kindness.
She was gentle, reverent,
cautious, and brief in words.
She could be used as a teacher for the child,
or at one time as an indulgent mother
and at another as a guardian nurse.
All dwelt in the children's room
in order to care for them fully;
others who had no business there, could not go there.
The Song says:
there were selling her sons and grandsons.
The nurse of the prince fled togehter with him.
She maintained her virtue,
managed her affairs,
and did not give them up for profit.
Thereafter she died without concern over it;
her honorary title was, "Xian I" or Illustrious Bequest."
The Song says:
When Qin was about to wipe out Wei,
there were selling her sons and grandsons.
The nurse of the prince fled togehter with him.
She maintained her virtue,
managed her affairs,
and did not give them up for profit.
Thereafter she died without concern over it;
her honorary title was, "Xian I" or Illustrious Bequest."
THE VIRTOUS AUNT OF LIANG
The virtous Aunt of Liang
was a woman of the [state] of Liang.
When her house caught on fire,
she was inside with her elder brother's child and her own child.
She wished to take up her brother's child
but in the rush she took her own son
and did not get her brother's son.
The fire was at its height
and she was unable to enter again.
The woman herself was about to rush into the flames.
Her friends stopped her,
saying,
"You originally wanted to take your elder brother's child
but being excited, in the end by mistake, you took your own son.- 110 -
A good conscience says, 'Why should you do this?
Why go to the extreme of rushing into the fire?'"
The woman replied,
"Can I allow this report to go throughout the state of Liang?
Bearing an unrighteous reputation
how can I face my brother and my countryman?
I would like to cast my son again into the fire
but this would violate a mothers love.
In such a situation I cannot go on living."
And afterwards she ran into the fire and died.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Wirtous Aunt was chaste and not debased.
The Book of Songs says:
"That great gentleman
would give his life rather than fail his lord."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The Virtous Aunt of Liang
held to righteousness and maintained her principles.
Her son and nephew were both in the house
when a great fire blazed up.
She wished to carry out her nephew,
but in her hurry took her own son.
When the fire was at its height she threw herself into it
to make clear that she was not a lover of self.
THE TWO RIGHTEOUS ONES OF ZHUYAI
The Two Righteous Ones
were the second wife of the magistrate if Zhuyai
and the daughter of the first wife.
The daughter's name was Chu
and she was thirteen years old.
[The district] of Zhuyai had many pearls
and the stepmother strung some large ones together for a forearm ornament.
When the magistrate died,
they had to accompany the funeral
and the law was
that one taking pearls through the pass would die.
The stepmother cast off her armlet of pearls
but her son, Nan, who was nine years old,
liked them and picked them up.
He placed them in his mother's dressing case
but no one knew of this.
Thereafter they escorted the funeral and returned.
When they reached the customs house,
the superintendentof customs searched [their baggage]
and found ten pearls in the stepmother's dressingcase.
The official said,
"Oh,
this is punishable by law; there is no help for it.
Who is the guilty one?"
Chu was nearby and thinking
fearfully in her heart that her mother would say that she [the mother] had put them in the dressing case,- 111 -
said,
"I, Chu, am the guilty one."
The official said,
"What declaration do you make about it?"
She replied,
"Our lord was unfortunate [and died];
his wife loosened her pearlarmlet and cast it aside
but Chu felt sorry for her in her heart
and took them up and placed them in the wife's dressing case
which she did not know."
When the stepmother heard this,
she went in haste to question Chu
but Chu said,
"The pearls which you cast aside,
Chu again took up
and placed them in the wife's dressing case.
Chu is the guilty one."
Although the stepmother thought that Chu ws being truthful
yet she pitied her and for this reason,
she said to the official,
"I wish to treat of this also.
Fortunately there is nothing for the child to be accused of,
as the child truly did not know of this.
These pearls are from my armlet.
My lord was unfortunate [and died];
I loosened [the pearls], took them off
and put themn in the case.
Being forced to accompany the funeral
on the long journey
and to be with the children,
I suddenly forgor them.
I am the guilty one."
Chu said determinedly,
"It was really Chu who took them."
The stepmother again said,
"But the child must give in to me;
it was really I who took them."
On this account, she was weeping and sniveling, and could not restrain herself.
The daughter also said,
"The sife pitied Chu who is an orphan
and she wishes to compel Chu to live.
The wife truly did not know about this."
And she, too, on this account cried and wept
until the tears ran down onto her neck.
The ones who were accompanying the funeral were all crying
and their grief moved the bystanders
[so that] there was no one who did not sniffle and wipe away his tears.
The customs official took his brush to write the accusation
but he could not complete a single character.
The custom official's tears rolled down [his cheeks]
and for the whole day he was unable to decide the case.
Then he said,
"Since the mother is as righteous as this,
I would rather stand the punishment myself;
I cannot bear to write the accusation.
Moreover, as they mutually give way to each other,
how can I know which one is the [guilty one]?"
Thereafter he cast away the pearls and let them go.
When they had departed,
they later learned that only Nan had taken [the pearls].
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Two Righteous Ones [were] kind and filial!
The Lun Yu says,
"The father conceals the misconduct of the son
and the son conceals the misconduct of the father.
Uprighthess is found in this."
If the stepmother and her adopted daughter argued and mutually gave place to each other in order to die for each other
and their grief moved bystanders,
that could be called righteousness.
The Song says:
The Lady of Zhuyai
had a mother's deep affecton.
The adopted daughter and stepmother mutually gave way to each other
but the daughter was virtous too.
Each one confessed
that she had taken the pearls through the customs
and the two virtous ones being such,
their story is written for the world.
THE LOVING YOUNGER SISTER OF HO YANG
The Loving Younger Sister
was the wife of Yenshou, the city official of Ho Yang.
Her first name was Jier
and she had three children.
Jier's elder brother, Jizong, was quarrelling with Yanshu over the matter of burrying his father
and Yanshou with his friend, Tianjian,secretly killed Jizong.
Jian alone was punished by death
and Yanshou was able to be pardoned.
he told this to Jier
and Jier said,
"Alas,
now you are alone and you tell this to me?"
Following this she shook the dust from her clothes
and said,
"Who was it that together with you killed my elder brother?"
Yanshou said,
"Tianjin
and he has died already;
I alone ought to be killed.
You kill me and all with be over."
Jier said,
"To kill one's husband is not righteous;
to serve the murderer of my elder brother likewise is not righteous."
Yanshou said,
"I do not dare to keep you here.
I wish to use a horse and cart together with all the household goods and things and to company
and to obey you in whatsoever you desire."
Jier said,
"What should I do?
My brother is dead and his murder is not avenged;
I share the same pillow and mat with you and yet you caused the murder of my brother.
I cannot be together sith you in the same house
and connive with the enemy of my elder brother.
How can I live face to face with him under the same sky and tread the same earth?"
Yanshou was ashamed and departed,
not daring to see Jier.
Jier then told her eldest daughter, saying,
"Your father killed my elder brother.
A righteous person could not remain here
and moreover to the end I could not marry again.
I shall leave you and die;
look well after your two younger brothers."
Following this she used a swadding cloth to commit suicide and died.
King Feng I heard of this in all its details
and extolled her righteousness.
He ordered the magistrate to restore her three children to liberty and made illustrioous her grave.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The loving younger sister well repaid her elder brother's enemy.
The Book of Songs says:
"Never usurp or go beyond your rights, //
And few will not take you as their model." //
Jier could be taken as a model.
The Song says:
Jier established righteousness.
Since her husband killed her elder brother,
she wished to repay her brother's murderer
but righteousness would not allow her to act.
She could neither remain with him nor leave him
[so] thereafter she brought calamity on herself.
King Feng I made illustrious her grave
and praised her glorious righteouness.
THE VIRTOUS WOMAN OF THE CAPITAL
