The Virtous Woman of the Capital
was a woman of the Da Chang section of Zhangan.
Her husband had enemies
who desired to seize him but they had no way of doing so.
They learned that his wife was kind, filial, and righteous,
and so they forcibly seized her father
in order to use his daughter as a go-between [to obtain their end].
The father called his daughter and told her about [the plan]
and the daughter thought within herself, "If I do not obey them, then I will cause the death of my father
and that is unfilial;
if I obey them,
then they will kill my husband
and that is unrighteous.
Who is there, if he is unfilial and righteous,
who can go on through life?
She wished to give her own life in his place
and gave her promise,
saying,
In the evening,
my husband washes himself
and sleeps in the first room in the east of the house; he will be there.
I promise to open the door and the window and to wait for them [i.e.,his enemies],"
She returned to her home
and spoke to her husband
that she might sleep in his place.
Then she washed herself in the first room room on the east of the upper storey,- 114 -
opened the window and door, and lay down.
At midnight
the enemies really came,
cut off her head, and carried it away.
In the morning when they looked at it,
[they saw] that it was the head of his wife.
The enemies were deeply grieved
and considered her as righteous.
Thereafter they gave up their designs and did not kill the husband.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The Virtous Woman was kind, filial, and generous in her benignity.
She placed great value on benignity and righteousness and slight value on death and ruin.
Her actions were those of a noble person.
The Lun Yu says,
The Superior Man will sacrifice his life to preserve his virtue complete.
He will not seek to live at the expense of injuring his virtue."
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The Virtous Woman of the Capital,
whose [husband's] enemies took her father by force
to make her act as a go-between,
did not dare promise [what they asked].
When the time and place were arranged,
she changed places with her husband.
Though they killed her body, they perfected her virtue.
In righteousness she ranked first in the whole empire.
JUAN VIJING, THE CONCUBINE OF GUAN OF QI
The concubine, Jing, was the concubine of Guan Zhong, Minister of Qi.
Ningqi wished to meet Duke Huan
but he had no way of doing so.
Then he played the part of a servant
and stopped his cart for the night just outside the East Gate [of the capital] of Qi.
When Duke Huan was going out,
Ningqi tapped on an ox's horn and sang
a mournful song.
Duke Huan thought it strange
and ordered Kuan Zhong to interview him.
Ningqi addressed him saying,
"How was the white waters!"
Since Guan Zhong did not understand what he was talking about,
he did not attend court for five days
and wore a sad countenance.
His concubine, Jing, entered [his room] and said,
"Now, my lord, you have not attended court for five days and you have a sad air about you;
I dare ask if it is on account of the nation's affairs
that you, my lord, are thus thinking?
Guan Zhong said,
"It is nothing that you know of."
Jing said,
"I have learned this,
'Do not treat the aged as aged;
do not treat the ignoble as ignoble;
do not treat the young as young;
and do not treat the weak as weak.'
Guan Zhong said,
"What does this mean?"
Jing said,
"Formerly, Tai Gong Wang at seventy was merely a bull slaughterer in the Chaoge Market;
but at eighty he was a tutor to the emperor;
and at ninety he was granted a fief in Qi.
From this it can be seen
whether the old may be treated as old?
When Yiyin
had the officer Xin as a favored official,
Tang raised him to the office of Guardian of the Heir Apparent
and his government of the empire was peaceful.
From this it can be seen
whether the ignoble may be treated as ignoble?
Yizi when he was five years old was helping Yu.- 116 -
From this it can be seen
wether the young may be treated as such?
Kuaiti, when seven days old outran his mother!
From this it can be seen
whether the weak may be treated as weak?"
Thereupon Guan Zhong knelt upon his mat and thanked her saying,
"Please tell me the meaning of this matter:
Some days ago,
the Duke ordered me to interwiev Ningqi
and he said,
'How vast the white waters!'
I did not know what he was speaking about
and that was the cause of my sadness."
His concubine laughingly said,
"The man has already told you, my lord.
Did my lord not discern that?
In ancient times there was a poem called, White Waters';
does not the poem say:
"'How vast the white waters! //
How mottled the fish! //
You, my lord, come to seek for me, //
But where shall I settle down? //
The nation is not yet tranquil; //
How shall it be with my followers?' //
It is Ningqi's desire to assist the government."
Guan Zhong rejoiced greatly
and reported this to Duke Huan.
Duke Huan then remodelled his official's quarters,
fasted, did not kill animals for five days;
then he interviewed Ningqi
in order to use him as his assistant.
The kingdom of Qi was then [well] ruled.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The concubine, Jing, is able to give counsel.
The Book of Songs says:
"The ancients had a saying: - //
'Consult the grass and firewood-gatherers.' " //
this could be said of her.
The Song says:
Duke Huan met Ningqi by chance
an ordered Guan Zhong to interwiew him.
Ningqi spoke of the "White Waters" [poem]
but Guan Zhong was sad and doubtful.
The concubine went in to him and asked about the mater
and explained the poem.
Guan praised her, reported it to the Duke,
and Qi gained the condition of being well ruled.
THE MOTHER OF JIANGYI OF CHU
She was the mother of Jiangyi, a minister of Chu.
Yi was minister in Ying
and there were some men who entered the king's palace there and robbed it.
The district magistrate considered Yi to be responsible
and asked the king to dismiss him.
Not long after, at Yi's home,
his mother lost eight fathoms of cloth.
Then she went and spoke to the king, saying,
"At night, I have lost eight fathoms of cloth.
The district magistrate stole it from me."
At that time the king was at the Litle Ballad terrace
and the district magistrate was attending him.
The king spoke to the mother saying,
"If the magistrate is really a robber,
then I, [the king], will not spare him punishment because of his wealth and honor;
if he is not a robber, then you have slandered him.
The Kingdom of Chu has regular laws [for such cases].
The mother said,
"The magistrate did not steal it personally;
however, he caused men to steal it."
The king said,
"He caused men to steal it! how is that?"
She replied,
"Formerly, when Sun Shuao was district magistrate,
if things were lost on the road, they were not picked up [by others];
doors were not locked;
and thieves and robbers of their own accord had ceased to exist.
Today, the rule of the district magistrate is such
that the ears and eyes [of the police] do not observe [crimes];
thieves and robbers go about in public.
For this reason he has caused robbers to steal my cloth;
this is how he has caused men to rob. What is strange about this?"
The king said,
"Since the district magistrate is in upper ranks [of society]
and the thieves are in the lower,
he did not know about them. how is he guilty?"
The mother said,
"Alas!
how can the King say this?
Some days ago, when my son was minister in Ying
and someone stole some articles from the King's palace,
my son was blamed and deprived of his office.
How could my son likewise know about the thieves?
But in the end he was made responsible for them.
What kind of a man is the district magistrate
that he alone should be thought faultless?
Formerly, King Wu of Zhou had a saying as follows,
'If common people have faults,
they are attributable to one man, [myself].'
The king said,
Very good.
This is not a criticism of the district magistrate alone
but of myself too."
he ordered the cloth to be returned to the mother
and on this account presented her with one thousand "yi" of money.
The mother declined the money and cloth saying,
"How shall I covet these goods and be a cause of loss to the Great King.
It was the government of the district magistrate that I complained of."
Thereafter she departed
and was unwilling to receive [the money and the cloth].
The king said,
"If the mother is as wise as this,
her son cannot be stupid."
Then he summoned back Jiangyi and employed him.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Yi's mother was excellent at using small matters to explain by example.
The Book of Songs says;
"[Thus] your plans do not reach far, //
And I therefore strongly admonish you." //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
Jiangyi lost his position
and his mother was moved.
When she returned home,
she had lost eight fathoms of cloth.
When she pointed out accusingly and reproached the district magistrate,
her speech and argument were well thought out.
The king again used Jiangyi
and rewarded the mother with money and cloth.
THE WIFE OF THE BOW-MAKER OF JIN
The wife of the bow-maker
was the daughter of a man of the Fan family of JIn.
In the time of Duke Ping,
the Duke ordered her husband to make a bow
and after three years it was completed.
Duke Ping drew the bow and let fly an arrow
but it did not pierce a thin wooden tablet.
Duke Ping, being angry,
was about to kill the bow-maker,
when the wife of the bow-maker asked to see him, sayhing,
"I am a child of the Fan family,
the wife of the bow-maker,
and I wish to have an interview with the ruler."
Duke Ping gave her an audience
and the wife said,
"Had the prince heard what Duke Liu formerly did?
The sheep and the cattle trampled the water grasses
and he who was sympathetic to the griefs of the people- 119 -
was kind even to vegetation.
How could he desire to kill an innocent one?
Duke Mu of Qin
had the robber eat the flesh of his race horse
and in turn gave him wine to drink.
The minister of King Zhuang of Chu raised the clothes of his wife
and the King broke off his hat tassel and drank with him with great pleasure.
These three rulers
had their kindness made known throughout the world.
When they died they enjoyed their reward
for their names for their names have been handed down even to our day.
Formerly, Lord Yao did not trim his thatched roofs,
nor carve his rafters;
his earthen steps were of three tiers
and yet he considered his actions as meritorious
and that living in such a house he was enjoying real leisure.
Today, my husband
has manufactured this bow
and it has also its merit.
The material for it grew on the south slope of the Tai Mountain;
in one day he examined three times both its Yin and its Yang.
The workman used a horn from a crow of Yen and bound it using the sinews of Brush Deer;
he glued it together with fish glue
and these four materials
were all chosen from the world's most extraordinary ones.
And thus, O lord, your not being able to pierce a wooden tablet
was due to your not being able to shoot an arrow.
Now on the other hand, you wish to kill my husband;
is not this also a mistake?
I have learned the art of archery!
The left hand is placed out strongly as if to resist
and the right hand as if holding a branch [without relaxing].
The right hand sends it forth
and the wrist of the left hanc does not bend.
this is the method of archery."
Duke Ping followed her instructions
and pierced seven wooden tablets.
The wife of the man of Fan obtained his acquittal
and was given a reward of three "yi" of money.- 120 -
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: The wife of the bow-maker could endure difficulties.
The Book of Songs says:
"The painted bows are strong, //

THE DISCRIMINATING WOMAN OF THE WASTELANDS OF CHU
The Discriminating Woman of the wastelands of Chu
was the wife of a man of the Zhao Family.
Duke Jian of Zheng had sent a messenger with bethrotal to [the state of Jing]
and when he came to a narrow road,
there was a woman riding in a cart
which struck the wheel of the official's cart.
When it broke the axle of the official's cart,
he became very angry,
and was about to beat her.
The woman said,
"The Superior Man does not shift the blame
nor does he repeat a fault.
Today, in this narrow road
I had already pulled over to the edge.
and your servant, O Minister, would not pull aside a little;
this is why yourt car was ruined.
But you turn about and seize me;
is not this to arouse your anger?
Since yiu are not angry with your servant
turn your hatred on me,
is not this to commit a second fault?
The Annals of Zhou say,
'Do not insult the widowers and the widows
and respect the lofty and intelligent.'
Today, great official that you are, you do not set a good exampl
but arouse your anger and commit a second fault.
you exonerate your servant and seize me;
you make lkight of my smallness and weakness.
cannot this be said to be insulting the widows and the widowers?
If you whip me then only I whipped
but I pity the ruin of your goodness, O Official."
The official was ashamed and was without words with which to reply.
Thereafter he freed her
and asked her who she was.
She replied, saying,
"I am a countrywoman of the wastelands of Chu."
The official said,
"Now follow me to Zheng!"
she replied, saying,
"Now, I have an humble husband
of the Zhao family at home."
Afterwards she departed.

The Discriminating Woman was able to speak so as to excuse and free herself. - 123 -

The envoy of Zheng was ashamed and departed,

THE YOUNG LADY AT AGU
The young lady at Agu
was a washwoman on the road of Agu。
Confucius, who was making a pleasure trip south,
was passing on the road of Agu
and saw the young lady who was wearing jade ornaments and was washing.
Confucius spoke to Zikong, saying,
"That woman washing there is able to talk well."
He took out a cup in order to give it to Zikong, saying,
"Use this as an excuse and we shall observe her determination."
Zikong said to her,
"I am a man of the northern country,
who is travelling from north to south,
and desires to go to Chu.
I have met with the summer heat,
and reflecting on its scorching hotness,
whish to beg a drink
to assuage my thirst."
The young lady said,
"The road of Agu
is a hidden a winding place;
its waters are now clear, now muddy,
as they flow on to the sea.
If you wish to drink, then drink of it
but why do you ask me, a poor servant maid?"
She took up the cup from Zikong,
dipped it into the flowing water and poured it out;
she took some again and threw it out.
She followed the current, poured it out,
and then filled it up to running over.
She knelt straight, put the cup on the sand,
and said,
"It is not proper to touch each other in handing this to you."
Zikong returned and reported the words,
whereupon Confucius said,
"I already knew this."
He took out his lute [used] to drive away the pigs
and gave it to Zikong, saying,
"Use this as an excuse."
Zikong went towards her saying,
"The one approaching you has heard your words- 124 -
which are as gratifying as a gentle breeze,
neither driving one away not rebuffing one,
but exhilarating my heart.
I have a lute which is not in tune
and I desire to ask you to harmonize its tones."
The young lady said,
"I am a rustic country girl,
untaught and thoughtless,
who does not know the five tones.
How could I tune the lute?"
Zikong gave it back to Confucius
and Confucius said,
"I knew it already.
She is very capable and yet respectful."
The he took out some fine and coarse linen fathoms, in order to give it to Zikong, saying,

Zikong approached her saying,

going from north to south,

which I should not dare exchange for your body.

The young lady said,
Travellers
have been passing here continually for a long time
and they divide their goods and wealth
and cast it to the rustic wilderness.
Since I am very young,
how should I dare accept you?
You have not married yet
and I have secretly learned the name of my humble husband."
Zikong reported these words to Confucius
and Confucius said,
"I already knew it.

JUAN, THE WOMAN OF THE FERRY IN ZHAO
Juan, the woman at the ferry in Zhao,
was the daughter of the officer of the ferry at the river in Zhao
and the wife of [King] Jianzi of Zhao.
In the beginning, when JIanzi was starting south to invade Chu,
he notified the officer of the ferry- 125 -
but when Jianzi arrived there,
the ferryboat officer was in a drunken sleep
and they could not cross the river.
Jianzi
wished to slay him,
and Juan, fearing greatly,
took up her oar and was departing.
Jianzi said,
O woman, why are you departing?"
She replied, saying,
"I am the daughter of the officer of the ferry.
My father having heard that you, O lord, were coming to ferry across the deep waters,
feared lest the wind would raise up waves
and the water spirit would be moved and aroused.
Therefore he prayed and sacrificed to the spirits of the Nine Rivers and the Three Huai [rivers].
Since he offered up complete and perfect ceremonies
to welcome and receive the blessings [of the spirits],
he did not leave one drop
in the sacrificial wine cup
and thus he became drunk.
If you, O lord, wish to kill him,
then I should like to use my poor person to exchange for my father's in dying."
Jianzi said,
"It was not your crime."
Juan said,
"You, O lord, wish to kill him because of his drunkenness
but I fear that his body will not feel the pain
and his heart will not know of his crime.
If he does not know of his crime and you kill him,
this is to kill an innocent man.
I desire him to awake and then you can kill him
thus causing him to know of his crime."
Jainzi said,
"Good!"
and thereafter he released him so that he was not punished by death.
Jianzi, being about to ford the river,
was short one rower
and Juan rolled up her sleeves, took an oar, and asked,
saying,
"I wish to fill the place of my father
and use his oar
Jianzi said,
"I, when about to travel,
picked out my ministers and officers,- 126 -
fasted, did not kill animals, and bathed.
It is not right to cross the river with a woman with us in the boat."
Juan said,
I have heard that formerly when Tang was attacking Xia,
on his left was a fleet female running-mate
and on his right a swift beautiful horse
thereafter he was able to banish Jie.
When King Wu was attacking Yin,
he had a dappled horse as running-mate to his team on his left
and on his right a red running-mate,
and thereafter he was able to subdue Zhou
at the height of the Hua Mountain.
If you do not wish to cross by ferryboat, that is another matter,
but what harm is there
in going in the same boat with me?？
Jianzi was pleased
and thereafter went in the same boat with her.
In the midstream she sang the song of the "Roaring River"
and her composition was as follows,
"He mounted the barge and his face beheld the pure stream.
The waters were lashed up in waves. How dark and cloudy!
His prayers asked blessings but he was drunk and did not awake.
The death penalty was about to be added and I was alarmed at heart.
The punishment was rescinded; the river became clear
and I took up an oar and held the painter [ferry].
the crocodile assisted but the ruler was about to turn back.
He called to her to come and row and they went ahead without suspicion."
The king was greatly pleased and said,
"Recently I dreamt that I took a wife.
Could this have been the girl?'
He sent an officer over to ask her
to become his wife.
Juan then made an act of reverance and declined, saying,
"The rules of propriety for marriage are
that without a go-between, one cannot be married.
I have strict parents at home
and I dare not obey your command."
When Jianzi returned home,
he
sent betrothal gifts to the father and mother
and established her as his wife.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
The girl, Juan, saw clearly through affairs and was able to explain them.
The Book of Songs says:
"We come to sport, we come to sing, //
To spread his fame. //
This could be said of her.

Jian of Zhao was about to cross the river

THE MOTHER OF FUXI OF ZHAO
The mother of Fuxi of Zhao
was the mother of Fuxi, an official of Zhong Mou of Zhao.
Fuxi caused Shong Mou to revolt
and the law of Zhao was
that if some one Caused a city to revolt,
he himself would be killed and his household would be seized.
The mother of Fuxi began to protest this [penalty],
she herself saying,
"I ought not to die."
The official asked for her reason
and the mother said,
"If I am able to reach the ruler,
then I shall speak;
if not,
then this old woman will die and that will end it."
The official related her words to Xiangzi
and Xiangzi ordered him
to inquire into her reason.
The mother said,
"If I do not obtain an audience with the sovereign, I shall not speak."
On this account, Xiangzi admitted her to an audience and asked her,
"Why is it that you ought not to die?
The mother said,
"Likewise, [tell me], how is it that I ought to die?"
Xiangzi said,
"Your son rebelled!"
The mother said,
"If the son rebels,
why should the mother die?"
Xiangzi said,
"The mother was not able to instruct her son,
and so she causes him to come even to rebellion.
How is it then, that the mother should not die?"
The mother said,
"Alas!
Now you use a reason for the ruler to kill me
because I did not instruct my son.
My duty was completed long ago
and this trouble rests with you the ruler.
I have learned that if the child is rude while young,
it is the mother's fault.
if when he grows up, one cannot use him,
that is his father's fault.
Now, in this case, when my son was small, he was not rude;
when he grew up he could be used also.
Where there any fault of mine?
I have also learned
that when a child is small, he is treated as a child;
when he is grown, he is treated as a friend;
and when your husband dies, then obey him.
I was able to raise my son for the ruler
and the ruler himself chose him as minister.
If you wish to come into discussion,
'This minister of the King
is not my son.
If the King has a cruel minister,
I did not have a cruel son!
This is to say that I am without fault.'
Xiangzi said,
"Good!
Then the rebellion of Fuxi
was my own fault."
Thereafter he freed Fuxi.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says:
The mother of Fuxi
in a word made clear her meaning to Xiangzi.- 128 -
She caused him to act virtously without shifting the blame to others
and escaped with her life.

"Now, that I have seen my lord //
My heart is eased."

THE CONCUBINE NEE YU OF CHI
The concubine nee Yu
was named Juan
and was the secondary wife of King Wei of Chi
While King Wei was on the throne,
he did not rule for nine years
but entrusted the government
to his prime minister.
The scheming minister Zhou Pohu had the sole power and usurped authority;
he was envious of the virtous and talented.
At that time, the official Mo had talent
and Pohu day after day defamed him,
while the official A was degenerate
and flattered him daily.
The concubine mee Yu spoke to the king, saying,
"Pohu
is a deceitful and flattering minister;
you cannot help but relieve him.
There is an official in the northern suburb of the capital of Chi
who being of high character and clear intelligence, acts by principle.
He could be commissioned to high office to assist you."
The concubine mee Yu spoke to the king, saying,
"Pohu
is a deceitful and flattering minister;
you cannot help but relieve him.
There is an official in the northern suburb of the capital of Chi
who being of high character and clear intelligence, acts by principle.

Pohu having heard of this,
then hated the concubine nee Yu and said,
"While she was a young girl living in a side lane,
she frequently had illicit relations with the official of the northern suburb."
The king was suspicious of her
and locked up the concubine nee Yu in the Nine-story Tower Tower
and then ordered the supervisor to examine the affair throroughly.
Pohu bribed the one managing the affair
to bring about the final establishment of her fault.
The manager falsified her reply and presented it to the king.
The king read the report
and it did not satisfy him
so he summoned the concubine nee Yu and personally questioned her.
The concubine nee Yu replied, saying,
"I am Juan who fortunately received my body through the kindness of my ancestors;- 129 -
when I was born here on earth,
I went out under the thatched hovels to live.
I waited on the pleasure of the intelligent King
and was closely attached to him,
preparing his bed, screen, mat,
and caring for the sweeping of the porches.
With my own hands I presented the warm water for bathing
and all of this up to the present has been ten years or more.
Then most anwious of heart
and hoping for the good fortune [of the country], I attempted to repair its fortune by word,
but on account of a crafty minister's push,
I sank down so deep as it were a hundred fathoms.
Unexpectedly then, the great King sees me again and speaks with me.
I have learned that the precious stone falling into the mud does not become unclean
and the deserted and lonely woman beneath the willow tree
is not considered a profligate.
These things have been in practice for a long time
and therefore they do not cause any suspicion.
One passing through a melon field should not stoop to tie one's sandals
and one passing through a plum orchard should not straighten one's hat.
These things I did not avoid
and that is one fault.
When I fell into this misfortune,
the official [examining my case] received a bribe
and obeyed the order of a wicked man
so that I was undermined by falsehood
and could not clear myself.
I have heard that the widow cried at the city wall
and the city wall on her account caved in;
the ruined scholar sighed in the market place
and the market on his account closed up.
Sincere loyalty flowed from the interior
and moved the city wall and the market place.
My injury was evident in broad daylight
yet I sobbed alone within the Nine-story Tower
while all knew nothing of it.
This was my second fault.
Since I had a tarnished reputation
and there was added this second fault,
a righteous and constant person could not continue to live;
yet I am alive
because no one has manifested my ill repute.
Moreover, from antiquity there were such cases;
Poji was sent away to the wastelands;
Shen Sheng suffered misfortune;
both were filial and obedient even to renown
but on the other hand they were considered as miscreants.
Since I have been condemned to die,
I shall not again address you
but I wish to admonish the great King
that all the officials are wicked
and that Pohu is the very worst.
If the King does not manage his government,
the country will be in great danger."
Thereupon the great king understood the affair
and went out with Yu
to show her into the court and the market place.
He granted a fief to the minister of Mo of ten thousand families
and boiled to death the officials A and Zhou Pohu.
Next he raised troops to take back his lands that were formerly usurped
and the state of Chi was startled and feared.
Since men knew that he boiled to death te minister A,
they did not dare gloww ofer their shortcomings- 130 -
and they dutifully fulfilled their offices.
The nation of Chi was well ruled.

The Book of Songs says:
"But now that I have seen my lord //
My heart is still." //
This could be said of her.

King Wei of Chi was neglectful of government
and did not rule actively for nine years.
The concubine nee Yu admonished him
but he in turn injured her personally.
The concubine narrated her affairs in order
and in doing so pointed to the high heaven [as her witness].
King Wei was awakened to understand
and in the end opposed the strong kingdom of Chin.
ZHONGLI CHUN OF CHI
Zhongli Chun
was a woman of the town of Wuyan of Chi
and was the legal consort of King Xuan.
She was an ugly person without equal
for she had a broad head with indentations
and sunken eyes,
long fingers
an big joints,
a turned up nose
and a swollen throat,
a thick neck
and little hair.
She was bent at the waist
with protuding bust;
her skin was dark as if it were warnished
and she was already forty years of age
and without a place to enter.
She offered herself for marriage without anyone taking her;
after being rejected she wandered about without any position.
On this account then she cleaned and tidied up her short rough clothes
an went personally to see King Xuan.
She spoke to the interwiever, saying,
"I am a woman of Chi who has not been bought in marriage.
Since I have heard of the wise virtue of the sovereign,
I desire to fill the office of sweeping the porches in the women's quarters of the palace
and I respectfully await the answer outside the Si Ma Gate
if the King graciously grant it.
The interwiever made this known to King Xuan
who was then giving a feast on the Jian Terrace
ad those about him having heard it,
All covered their mouhs with sleeves and said,
"This greatest beauty of the Empire!
How extraordinary she must be!"
The Song says:
On this account then King Xuan summoned her that he might see her- 131 -
and spoke to her saying,
"Some time ago, the former king had chosen the ladies of the palace for me
and all have already fulfilled their ordered positions.
Today, you, a woman whom not even country village can find place for, you, who are in cotton clothing,
wish to have as a mate the lord of ten thousand chariots;
now what remarkable ability have you?"
Zhongli Chun replied, saying,
"I have none
but I have specially and secretly loved the righteousness of the great King."
The king said,
"Even so,
what joy is there in that?"
After a good while she said,
"I secretly partake of a joy of becoming invisible."
King Xuan said,
"Invisible! That is certainly what I desire.
Try to do it at once."
His words were not yet finished
and suddenly he could not see her.
King Xuan was startled,
rose, took up Yin Book and read it.
Though he thought and reasoned on it
yet he could not understand it.
On the following day,
he again summoned her and questioned her
on her invisibility.
She only raised her eyes, ground her teeth,
raised her hands, slapped her knees,
and said,
"Danger! Danger!
Like this four times!"
The king said,
"I desire to hear and follow your instructions."
Zhongli Chun said,
"Today, the great King is ruling this nation
and on the west side you have the danger of an equally strong Chin;
on the south there is a rival in the powerful Chu.
Fom the exterior there are difficulties from two countries;
at home you have a horde of wicked officials
whom men will not obey.
Although forty springs and autumns have passed [in your rule],
you have not yet set up a strong son [as your heir];
you do not concern yourself over your host of sons but over your crowd of wives.
You honor those you like
and slight those upon whom you are depending.
Some morning the mountain will fall in ruins
and the gods of the state will be unsettled.- 132 -
This is the first danger!
You have raised a terrace, adorned with five thicknesses
of yellow gold and precious stones,
using white coral in open lattice-work, jadite, pearls,
and curtains tied together as adornments,
while all the common people are wearied to the utmost.
This is the second danger!
There are able men hiding in the groves on the hills,
while flatterers and tricksters are entrenched all about you.
The wicket and false are given positions in your court
and the Admonitor cannot get through to reach you.
This is the third danger!
You are drinking wine and lost in drunkenness
that runs through days and succeeding nights
Women, music, theatrical shows are all in the buildings
which ring with loud laughter.
Outside the palace, the ceremonies of the nobles are not practiced
while inside you do not direct the government of the nation.
This is the fourth evil!
For this reason, I said, "Danger! Danger! "
Thereupon, King Xuan sighed deeply and said,
"Alas, the words of the lady of Wuyan!
Now, today, I have heard them once!"
Then he destroyed the Jian Terrace,
put a stop to the women and music,
retired the fawning flatters,
and sent away the cutters and polishers of jewels.
He gathered his soldiers and horses,
filled his treasuries and grain depots,
and put in order the public gates on all sides.
He summoned into his court those who spoke the plain truth,
received the humble and lowly,
and by divination selected a lucky day
and established the heir apparent.
He promoted the mother of the heir
and honored the Lady of Wuyan as his queen.
Then the Kingdom of Chi enjoyed great peace
ad this was due to the power of an ugly woman.
The Man of Noble Sentiments says: Zhongli Chun was upright and eloquent.
The Book of Songs says:
"I have seen my lord, //
And my heart is glad." //
This could be said of her.
THE SU WOMAN WITH THE GOITRE OF CHI
The Su Woman with the goitre
was the daughter of a mulberry leaf picker of the eastern suburb [of the capital] of Chi,
and later was the queen of King Min.
There was a large goitre in her neck
and for this reason she was called "Su of the Goitre."
In the beginning,
King Min went out on a pleasure excursion
and came to the eastern suburb
where all the common people were looking at him.
Su of the Goitre kept on picking mulberry leaves as before
and the king wondered about it.
He called her and sked her about it, saying,
"When I go out for a pleasure trip
in a carriage with many accompanying me,
there is no one of the common people, young or old, who does not drop his work and come to look at us.
You kept on picking mulberry leaves by the roadside
and did not even cast one glance at me.
Why is this?"
She replied, saying,
I received instructions from my father and mother to pick mulberry leaves
and I did not receive any order to stare at the great King."
The king said,
"This is a remarkable girl!
What a pity she has a goitre!
The girl replied,
"The duty of a humble handmaiden
is to be single-minded.
As long then, as I do not forget that [principle],
my conscience says,
'Why, what harm is there in having a goitre?'"
The king was highly pleased at this and said,
"This is truly a talented woman."
He ordered her to be carried in one of the carriages behind him
but the woman said,
"I am at the mercy of the King's strength,
and my parents are at home.
You will cause me to disobey my parents' instructions
and follow the great King.
such a one is a runaway girl!
how can your majesty thus want to use me?"
The king was ashamed
and said,
"This is my mistake."
And again he said,
"Unless every ceremoney is fulfilled, the chaste girl will not obey a command,
even to save her life."
On this account the king let her go, returned home,
and sent an officer with an added hundred "yi" of money as a betrothal gift
to go and meet her.
The father an mother were surprised and excited
and they wished to wash her
and dress her up.
The girl said,
"I was like this when I saw the king
ad if you change my appearance and my clothes,
he will not recognize me.- 134 -
I ask leave to die and mot to go."
On this account
she followed the officer just as she had been.
The king being greatly mortified, said
"Do not laugh! She is not made up; that is all!
If you compare one who is made up with one who is not,
the first is better by a thousand times."
The girl said,
"If one who is made up
is better a thousand ten thousand times,
it still cannot be said to be enough.
Why do you say just a thousand times?"
The king said,
"How do you explain that?"
She replied, saying,
"[Original] human nature is uniform
but in practice it varies.
In former times, Yao, Shun, Qie, and Zhou
were all emperors.
Yao and Shun considered righteousness and kindness to be true adornments of self
and although they were emperors,
they were content in being strictly economical.
They did not trim their thatched roofs
nor hew and carve their rafters;
neither did they allow richness of dress
and luxury of food in the women's quarters.
For thousands of years untill today,
the empire has glorified them.
Qie and Zhou did not deem righteousness and kindness as self adornments
and they considered their practice as troublesome non-essentials.
They built high pleasure-towers and deep pools;

to utter all my stupid words."

he interwiever said,

one who is driven from her neighborhood five times

and the wife of Ling of Zhao was called Mengyao
she was the daughter of Wu Guang and the queen of King Wu ling of Zhao.
In the beginning,
when King Wu Ling of Zhao bethrothed a daughter of King Han
who gave birth to a son, Zhang,
the king established her as a queen consort
and Zhang as crown prince.
The king frequently dreamt that he saw a maiden
playing a lute and singing this song:
"That handsome person! How resplendent! //
her beauty is the glory of a bignonia. //
O Fate! O Fate!
When she meets Heaven's own time, //
she will live, but she is not yet sprung forth." //
Another day
when the king was drinking wine happily,
he spoke of what he had dreamed
and longed to see the person [of his dreams].
Wu Guang heard of this
and by the help of the queen, sent his daughter Meng Yao into the palace.
She was most attractive
and the king so loved and favored her,
that he was unable to leave her.
After several years
she gave birth to a son,Ho,
and then Meng Yao frequently insinuated that the queen had adulterous intentions
and that the crown prince lacked the deportment of filial devotion.
then the king set aside the queen and crown prince
and established Meng Yao as Queen Hui
and made Ho, king.
He was known as King Hui Wen.
Wu Ling called himself the Lord Father
and granted a fief to Zhang
whom he called Lord of Anyang.
Four years later,
King Hui Wen was receiving many ministers at court
and the Lord of Anyang came also.
The Lord Father secretly watched the host of ministers
and he noticed that Zhang was weary and tired;
he was merely minister to his younger brother, Ho
and in his heart he pitied him.
At the time when Queen Hui died and the king's favor had long been declining,
The Lord Father wished to divide the state of Zhao in order to make Zhang, king of Dai.
The plan was not yet determined upon when it was stopped.
The Lord Father was on a pleasure trip to Sha Qiu's palace
and Zhang used foot soldiers to stir up a rebellion.
Li Tui called out the troops of the four capital cities and attacked Zhang
who fled to the Lord Father.- 162 -
The Lord Father admitted him
an on this account, Dui surrounded his palace.
When [Dui] had killed Zhang,
he plotted with the ministers saying,
"Use the [pretext of capturing] Zhang to surround the Lord Father!
Even if I release the soldiers,
I belong to the barbarian tribes anyway."
Then they immediately surrounded the Lord Father too,
who wanted to go out and was unable to do so
nor could he obtain anything to eat.
He took a baby sparrow and ate it;
after three months and more,
he died of hunger at Sha Qiu's palace.

when he beheld the concubine and kept her near,

later he set aside the queen and started emmities.

QUEEN NEE LI OF KING KAO OF CHU
Queen nee Li of [King] Kao of Chu
was the younger sister of Li Yuan, a native of Zhao,
and the queen of King Kao Lie of Chu.
In the beginning
King Kao Lie was without children
and the Lord of Chunshen was grieved by it.
While Li Yuan was a lodger in the home of this Lord of Chunshen
he gave the lord his younger sister in marriage.
When she knew that she was pregnant,
she took the opportunity of a leisure moment with him to say,
"The King of Chu favors and honors you, my lord,
in a much greater way than he does his own brothers.
Now, you have been minister of Chu for more than thirty years
but the king is without a son
and after his death
his brothers will be established in power.
When the state of Chu has established another ruler,
then each one will honor his relatives
and how will your favorable position last?
Though
you have served your lord for long time,
When the king's brothers are established in power,
then misfortune will come upon you.
How long will you be able to preserve your ministership and your feudal estate of the east river?
Now, I know that I am pregnant
but others do not know it
nor have I been the concubine of the favored minister for long.
Thruthfully, if I use your influence to enter the palace as a concubine for the King of Chu,
he certainly will take me for his concubine.
I trust in Heaven to give birth to a male child
and then your child will be king.
With the kingdom of Chu entirely in your power,
who then will allow unexpected revenge to fall upon you?"
The Lord of Chunshen highly approved of her proposal.
He took the younger sister of Yuan from his home and carefully sheltered her in another house.
Next he spoke to King Kao Lie
who summoned her to the palace and was pleased with her.
Afterwards, she gave birht to a son, Dao,
who was made crown prince.
Yuan's sister was made queen
and Yuan was honored by being used in the royal service.
He maintained some soldiers as he desired to kill the Lord of Chunshen and thus seal his mouth.
When King Kao Lie died,
Yuan then killed the Lord of Chunshen
and destroyed his family.
Dao ascended the throne
to become King Yu。
Afterwards King Yu died and King Kao Lie's posthumous son, Yu, was established
as King Ai.
King Kao Lie's younger brother, a follower of the Prince Fu Chu, heard and understood that King Yu was not King Kao Lie's son
and he was suspicious of King Ai.
The he attacked and killed King Ai and the queen dowager;
he completely destroyed the house of Li Yuan
and established Fu Chu as king.
Five years later
the state of Qin destroyed them too.
The Book of Songs says,
"Their [the scoundrels'] words are very sweet, //
And the disorders thereby advance." //
This could be said of her.
The Song says:
The younger sister of Li Yuan rose to favor
through the importance of Chunshen.
When King Kao Lie was without a son,
she really brought it about that she became his wife.
Since she knew that she was pregnant, she gained entrance into his harem
and her son became the heir.
Thus the seed of rebellion was sown
and her clan was wiped out by death.
THE SINGING-GIRL QUEEN OF KING DAO OF ZHAO
The Singing-girl Queen
was a singing-girl of Hantan
and the consort of King Dao Xiang of Zhao
who in her earlier days had thrown into disorder her entire ancestral clan.
When she was a widow,
King Cao Xiang, having noticed her beauty,
betrothed her but Limu criticized him, saying,
"You should not do this!
This woman is not upright
and will cause the nation to become unstable and unsettled.
Does not the fact that she brought disorder to her whole clan
cause the great King to fear?"
The king said,
"The difference between disorder and a lack of disorder
lies in my ability to govern."
Then he married her.
In the beginning,
the queen of King Dao Xiang gave birth to a son, Jia, who became the crown prince.
The Singing-girl Queen then entered the palace as royal concubine
and gave birth to a son, Qian.
When the Singing-girl Queen was the king's favorite concubine,
she slandered the queen and the crown prince to the king,
and caused men to oppose the crown prince and to involve him in crime.
Then the king cast off Jia and established Qian as his crown prince;
he degraded the queen and made the Singing-girl Consort his queen.
When King Dao Xiang died,
Qian ascended the throne
and became King Yu Min.
The Singing-girl Queen, who was viciously licentious and unprincipled,
had relations with the Lord of Chun Ping
and received numerous bribes from the state of Qin.
When she had caused the king to put to death his best general, Jimu, Lord of Wuan,
then the soliers of Qin entered the country
and no one was able to oppose them.
Qian was taken as a prisoner to Qin
and the state of Zhao was ruined.
The minister was displeased because the Singing-girl Queen had slandered the crown prince and killed Limu,
so he killed her and destroyed her family.
He set up Jia as king in Dai
but during seven years
could not overcome the forces of Qin
Thereafter Zhao was wiped out as a kingdom.

The Singing-girl Queen of Dao of Zhao
was insatiable in her desire to gratify her appetites.
When she had caused the queen to fall from favor, she herself superseded he.

she satisfied all her desires,

she herself died and caused the ruin of the nation.
